text: It nearly fills the screen, swimming mysteriously in the warm late summer air. SOUND: Crickets.

head_text.subj: EXT. TRAIN TRACKS IN THE COUNTRY NIGHT

text: A rail-rider comes chugging along the tracks. Aboard is ARNIE WESTRUM, a big man in a strappy T-shirt and chino pants. He is drinking beer. ARNIE (sings) My beer is Rheingold the dry beer... Think of Rheingold whenever you buy beer... He drains the rest of his own bottle of Rheingold and tos it to one side. Up ahead we see a switching point. ARNIE throws the rail-rider into neutral, opens the toolb on the back, and brings out a big five-cell flashlight. H shines it on the switch. He gets a crowbar from the toolbox, plus a big wrench, a pair of pliers, a hammer, and a pair of work gloves. He a gets another bottle of beer and sticks it into his back pocket. ARNIE jumps down and approaches the switch. CREDITS CONTINUE.

head_text.subj: EXT. ARNIE, AT THE SWITCHING POINT NIGHT

text: He drops his tools, pulls on his work gloves, and trains light on the switch for a moment. During this: ARNIE (sings) It's not bitter, not sweet, it's a real frosty treat, won't you try, won't you buy Rheingold beer... He tries the switch. No go. It's frozen.

Stuck tighter'n dogshit in a deep freeze! He takes the bottle of beer from his back pocket and fish a churchkey from one of the front ones. He pops the cap a drinks deeply. He burps. Then he screws the half-empty bottle of beer into the cinders so it won't fall over. Th he picks up his crowbar. CREDITS CONTINUE.

There's a SOUND of bushes shaking. Something comes out - something huge. It leaps limberly onto the rail-rider. It a werewolf with greenish-yellow eyes. Tatters of clothes still hang from it. What kind of monster, exactly? It is humanoid as well as wolfish... and when we learn who it is in its human form, should be able to spot the resemblance at once...and kick ourselves for not knowing earlier. It crouches there, huge and bushy and fanged and deadly, the whole rail-rider. CREDITS CONCLUDE.
He's working the crowbar into the junction point just as hard as he can. Swearing at it under his breath. Suddenly both the tracks and the switch move.
Hot damn! Now... a little oil... He turns back toward the rail-rider.

head_text.subj: EXT. ARNIE, ARRIVING AT THE RAIL-RIDER NIGHT

text: It's not bitter, not sweet... it's a big fuckin' treat... A NOISE - bushes rattling; cinders clinking and rattling. ARNIE looks around.
Nothing there. His bottle of beer stands by the litter of his tools.

head_text.subj: EXT. ARNIE, AT THE RAIL-RIDER NIGHT

text: He's rooting around in the toolbox, back to the switching point.

head_text.subj: EXT. ARNIE'S BOTTLE OF BEER, CU NIGHT

text: A hairy hand/paw closes around it - we see huge curved cl on that hand.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE WEREWOLF'S FACE, CU NIGHT

text: Glaring green-yellow eyes; a savage, beastial face which still half human. That's all we see. The rest is in shado It opens its mouth and upends the bottle of beer. Foamy Rheingold begins gurgling down the werewolf's throat.

head_text.subj: EXT. ARNIE AT THE RAIL-RIDER NIGHT

text: He comes up with an old-fashioned oilcan, the kind with t long spout. He starts back to the switching point, waving the can. ARNIE (sings) My beer is Rheingold the dry beer... Think of Rheingold whenever you fry beer... He arrives, looks down... and stops singing. His eyes wid
We can see the hole where ARNIE put his beer, but it is o course empty. Beside it are two huge prints in the cinder half wolf, half human.
He's beginning to be afraid. Beginning to look around to what might be out here with him. Beginning to realize he in extremely deep shit.
It rises up on its hind legs, eyes glaring an ugly yellow green. Its snout wrinkles back, revealing those teeth.
He's craning back to look at the thing, his face a grue o horror.
Oh n- A huge clawed hand/paw comes sweeping down. ARNIE's head granted an immediate Reno-style divorce from the rest of body.

SOUND of the beast approaching. A hairy arm and taloned h reaches into the toolbox bolted to the back and rummages. The hand is dripping blood. It comes up with a bottle of Rheingold. The WEREWOLF begins to sing. It is a bizarre funny-horrib grunting, the words hellishly recognizable. WEREWOLF (gutteral; subhuman) My beer is Rheingold the dry beer... No bottle opener for this thing; it brings the neck of th bottle down sharply on the edge of the toolbox. Beer foam out.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE WEREWOLF'S FACE, IN DEEP SHADOW NIGHT

text: He/It rams the jagged neck of the bottle deep into its mo and drinks. Foam drizzles down its pelt. It's grinning. WEREWOLF (snarling voice) Think of Rheingold whenever you buy beer...

The bottle is empty. There are CRUNCHING SOUNDS as it beg to eat the bottle. Blood begins to run out of its mouth; its face wrinkles i pain and fury. It spits out broken, bloody jags of glass. Looks up. It HOWLS.

We're looking at Main Street of a small country town - mi be New England, might be mid-South. Might be 1984, might 1981. This is Tarker's Mills, and in places like this, ti moves more slowly. Cars - not too many - move back and forth. No one is in a hurry. We see the Methodist church (and the parsonage next door) Andy's Sporting Goods; Owen's Pub, with its Narragansett neon sign. We see a barber shop with a striped pole; we s the Holy Family Catholic Church and the rectory next door We see the Gem Theater, which is showing a revival of Sop Loren in "Two Women." It's Our Town, U.S.A. JANE (voice-over) This place is Tarker's Mills, where I grew up... and this is how it was when I was fourteen - a place where people cared about each other as much as they cared about themselves. This is how my town looked as, all unknowing, it approached the rim of the nightmare. The killing had begun. SOUND: The HOWL of the WEREWOLF - distant, a bit dreamy.

a.) VIRGIL CUTTS, owner of Virgil's Texaco, is filling up car. We hear the HOWl... and VIRGIL looks up uneasily. b.) In the barber shop, BILLY McCLAREN, the barber, is ju taking the apron off the Methodist minister, REV. O'BANIO They both look around. c.) Folks are coming out of the Gem Theater. They pause a the sound of that HOWL and look toward the edge of town.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE SETTING MOON, CU NIGHT

text: As JANE speaks, we see the moon sink below the horizon. JANE (v-o) The killing had begun, but at first no one knew it. Arnie Westrum was a chronic drunk, and what happened seemed like an accident.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE RAIL-RIDER AND ARNIE'S HEADLESS BODY NIGHT

text: Slowly the view improves, grows lighter, as we TIME-LAPSE DAWN. SOUND: A train is approaching. We hear its horn. CAMERA MOVES IN. Here is a shattered Rheingold bottle. Th is a litter of ARNIE'S tools. And here, on the cheek of ARNIE'S severed head, a few ants are checking things out. SOUND: The train's horn, MUCH CLOSER. JANE (v-o) The county coroner concluded that Arnie passed out on the tracks. There wasn't enough evidence to conclude anything else. And suddenly the train comes smashing into the frame, hor blaring. The rail-rider goes flying. ARNIE'S body disappe underneath. We see something flopping and moving under there. It could be a bundle of rags. Could be... but isn'

head_text.subj: EXT. TARKER'S MILLS TOWN COMMON DAY

text: The common is more or less in the center of town, either surrounded by Main Street commerce or backed by it. THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN on a big tent that's been erected the Common - looks like a revival meeting tent, almost, b the banner draped over the entrance reads: SUPPORT THE

Behind or to the side, on the grass, picnic tables have b set out end-to-end. Women are putting salads and home-bak breads on these - just about the whole town is going to s down to a meal when the meeting's over. Further off, men tending barbecues, roasting corn, etc. JOE HALLER (amplified voice) I'd like to give you Father Lester Lowe, of Holy Family Catholic Church! Enthusiastic applause greets this.

Most of the town is here, seated on folding chairs. We're looking particularly at three people - NAN COSLAW, her husband BOB, and their fourteen-year-old daughter, JANE. is JANE - a slightly older JANE - who we have heard speaking. She is now a bit bored with the meeting, which been going on for some time. As the APPLAUSE CONTINUES, s leans toward her mother.
I'm going out for a while, 'kay?

All right. Stay close. And make sure your brother's all right. As JANE gets up, the applause starts to fade a bit. NOTE: JANE is wearing a silver crucifix, and will continu to wear it through the whole movie.

To one side is a big black-and-white photograph on an eas It shows a van which has been customized into an emergenc medical unit. Behind the podium are four chairs. REV. TOM O'BANION sits one of them. ANDY FAIRTON sits in another, red-faced and beaming. JOE HALLER, the town constable, is just returnin to his; LESTER LOWE is just approaching the mike as the applause dies. LOWE'S face shines with love and goodwill.
For the last ten years... No amplification. He taps the mike.

She is making her way down the row to the aisle (the peop should be seated in folding chairs). She passes a GIRL of about her own age who has overheard NAN'S parting shot. GIRL (mocking) "Make sure your brother's all right." JANE (low) Marty's a booger. She reaches the aisle and starts out.
He taps the mike again.

location: THE CROWD, FEATURING BOB AND NAN COSLAW

text: BOB (good-natured) Just pretend you're in your own church askin' for money, father! It'll work fine! Good-natured laughter greets this.
A bit flustered, he taps the mike and is rewarded by a BR SCREAM OF FEEDBACK.

For the last ten years, I have had a dream. A dream of a time when modern medical care would come to this small community, which sometimes seems so far from Durham, with her lifesaving hospitals. I hope that this meeting, at which I see so many of my friends gathered, will be the start of making my dream come true. SOUND: Enthusiastic applause.

location: A SNAKE IN THE GRASS, CU

text: It's a blacksnake... harmless, but big. It goes wriggling through the grass toward a stream. In the b.g. - SOUND OF APPLAUSE. MARTY (voice) Holy...! Brady, are you sure they're not poisonous? BRADY (voice) Little old blacksnake? Hell, no! Hands - the rather grimy hands of a boy bent on mischief grab the blacksnake.
BRADY holds the snake up. Both boys gaze at it with respectful wonder. NOTE: MARTY is wearing a silver St. Cristopher's medallio and will through the whole movie.
Lemme hold him! BRADY hands it over. As MARTY looks at the snake, BRADY sees:

head_text.subj: EXT. JANE, COMING OUT OF THE TENT DAY

text: JANE (v-o) I was almost fifteen that summer. My brother Marty was eleven. Marty and his friend Brady Kincaid were the crosses I had to bear. Brady was actually the worse of the two, but I was rarely disposed to see that. Not when my younger brother was so constantly thrown in my face by my parents. LOWE (v-o from the tent) $32,000 is a lot of money. But when you think of the lives this unit might save, it seems very inexpensive indeed. Applause greets this.
Again we are fairly tight on the boys - we see them from waist or chest height. BRADY snatches back the snake.
I got an idea.
What? BRADY looks toward JANE. MARTY follows his gaze. His eyes widen.
You wouldn't. BRADY grins. MARTY assesses the grin.
You would.
An endeavor like this seems to me to be the very definition of community - all of us pulling together as one, farmers and merchants... Protestants and Catholics...

She is walking slowly toward the picnic area, and is pass under a tree. There's more applause from the tent. BRADY (teasing voice) Jane... Jane... She looks up. The blacksnake dangles down toward her, alm touching her upturned face. JANE shrieks and bolts. She gets a little way, trips over her own feet and falls down hard. She's wearing what was nice jumper and nylons. Now the jumper is torn and the ho shredded at the knees.
He's lying over a limb with the snake in his hand, laughi wildly.
She gets up, looks at her clothes, her bloody knees. She' near tears.

location: MARTY, AT ONE SIDE OF THE TREE, FAIRLY TIGHT

text: The shot's from the chest up. He looks sorry he was a par of this little stunt, as he ought to be.
It was just a blacksnake, Jane-
She looks around at him in a fury of embarrassment and something very close to hate.
Look at my knees! Look at my dress! I hate you!
Did wittle Janie make wee-wee in her teddies?
Stop it, Brady.
He throws the snake.
She dodges the snake with a little scream. She's beginnin to cry, but she flips BRADY the bird just the same.
Ooooh, naughty!
He moves toward JANE - there is something queerly unnatur in this movement, and in a moment we'll understand, but f the time being we must be puzzled.
Jane, I'm sorry. It was just a joke. We didn't mean- He's reached her. JANE is sobbing now, hysterical.
Oh, no! You never mean to! I hate you, you booger! She runs away.
He swings down and comes over to MARTY. BRADY (with satisfaction) Really got her goat that time.
He's in a wheelchair, looking glumly after JANE.
Oh, shut up, Brady. You're warped.

head_text.subj: EXT. NEAR THE BANDSTAND, FEATURING JANE DAY

text: She's walking slowly along, still crying a little. Now sh steps behind some bushes, looks around, hikes up the skir of her jumper, and wriggles out of the wrecked panty hose STELLA RANDOLPH (voice) Wait! Don't go! Startled, JANE looks around, instinctively yanking her dr down. No one in sight. MAN (voice; rough) Just leave me alone! Now she looks toward:

A man who looks like he might be a traveling salesman who has just stepped whole and breathing from a dirty joke ab the farmer's daughter comes striding down from the bandstand. STELLA RANDOLPH, a plump but sweetly pretty girl, comes t the stairs but does not descend them. She is also crying but these are real tears, folks. STELLA is a human Niagar Falls. STELLA (calls) Please! You have to help me!
DECEIVER (keeps walking) It's your oven, but it ain't my bun you're baking in there. Sorry, babe. B.g. SOUNDS: More applause.

We can hear STELLA sobbing as JANE walks slowly toward th bandstand with her panty hose still balled up in one hand JANE looks suddenly aware that she's not the only one in this sad world who has troubles. She reaches the foot of stairs going up to the bandstand and tosses the hose absently in a litter can. JANE mounts the steps timidly.
Stella? Is that you?

STELLA has retreated to one of the benches, where she is bawling into a handful of Kleenex. Pudgy and twenty-two, is both funny and terribly sad. She looks around at the sound of JANE's voice. STELLA (alarmed) Who - ? JANE (approaching closer) It's Jane, Stella. Jane Coslaw. STELLA sees it is, and turns away from her, still weeping JANE stands, uncertain what to do next. After a moment sh approaches closer and touches STELLA'S turned back timidl JANE (tenderly) What's wrong? STELLA (weeping) He's going away. I know he is.
Who's going away? STELLA turns to her, weeping still and distracted.
What am I going to tell my mother? If he won't marry me, what am I going to tell my mother? JANE (bewildered) Stella, I don't know what-
Oh, leave me alone! Just leave me alone, you stupid thing! STELLA lumbers across the bandstand and down the steps. J stares after her, bewildered and perhaps even a little frightened.
Let us pray.
Most of them bow their heads.
May the Grace of God shine upon those gathered here... and lift them up... and grant success to the endeavor to which they have so openheartedly declared their support. Amen.
They raise their heads. Some echo the "Amen." Others cros themselves.
People are coming out and getting ready to chow-down.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE COSLAW STATION WAGON DAY

text: Traveling along a country road. Headed home.

BOB and NAN COSLAW are sitting up front. MARTY and JANE a in the backseat. JANE is as far from MARTY as she can get She's still mad as hell. Band-Aids crisscross her knees. MARTY'S wheelchair is collapsed in the cargo area of the wagon. NAN turns around to look at the kids - and it's really JA she's mad at.
I want you two to bury the hatchet. You're being very silly, Jane. JANE (hot) Did you see my knees?
Jane, I-

I think you're being mean as well as silly. Your brother has never had a scraped knee in his whole life. Well, here it is - the chief source of JANE'S animus agai her brother and the source of most of the tension in the COSLAW family. MARTY winces and turns away a little, embarrassed - this always happens. He doesn't like it, but he doesn't know h to make his parents - his mother in particular - quit it.
You always take his side because he's a cripple! Well, it's not my fault that he's a cripple!
Come on, Jane- it was Brady's idea. I couldn't stop him.
Brady's a booger and so are you!
Jane Coslaw! BOB (roars) Stop it or I'll throw the whole bunch of you out! In this traditional family unit, BOB is the Voice of Authority. They all heed, although the atmosphere remains thundery.
Train tracks run near the road.

head_text.subj: INT. THE STATION WAGON, ENSEMBLE DAY

text: BOB (points) That's where poor old Arnie Westrum pitched his last drunk. He crosses himself and they all look toward:
They had to pick up what was left of him in a peach basket.
Oh, Daddy! Gross!
Did he really get his head cut off, Dad? That's what Brady said.
If you don't stop it I'm going to vomit. I mean it. NAN (no sympathy) You're not going to vomit, Jane. And I think we've all had quite enough of this horror-movie talk.
Craning back to look at the spot where ARNIE bit the dust His face is thoughtful, solemn.
JANE is lying in bed, her face to the wall. Dim light fal on her unhappy face as the door is opened. MARTY (v-o) Janey?... Are you awake? JANE says nothing.

head_text.subj: INT. THE DOOR TO JANE'S BEDROOM, WITH MARTY NIGHT

text: He is in his "house wheelchair" - not the Silver Bullet ( was in the Bullet during the Common scene, but we didn't a very good look at it). He has some stuff on his lap. A box, for sure.
Can I come in?
Her eyes are open but she says nothing. Just looks at the wall.
He rolls across to her bed and puts something on her nigh table. SOUND of change and a rattle of paper. She rolls o and sees he's put about three bucks on the table. Plus a of mixed nuts.
What's the money for?
A new pair of panty hose. Is it enough?
I don't want your money. You're a booger.
It was Brady's idea, Jane. Honest to God. Please take the money. I want to make up. She looks at him and sees he's sincere - honestly contrit She softens. There's hope for these two kids yet, maybe.
I can get a pair of L'Eggs down at the pharmacy for a dollar forty-nine. Here. She pushes the rest back to him, then looks at the can. S picks it up, curious.
That's for you, too. Uncle Al gave it to me- JANE (scorn) That drunk!

-but I want you to have it. He gives her a warm, melting smile. When your little brot is being good to you it's time to watch out - but JANE ha been lulled. She starts to open it, then looks questionin at him.
Yeah, go ahead. She opens it. A long paper snake - the kind with a spring inside it - leaps out. She shrieks.
You booger! MARTY backs up the wheelchair so he's out of her reach. MARTY (grinning) It really is for your birthday, though - try it on Brady. He'll wet his pants.
Go to hell!
MARTY (smiling) I love you, Janey.
She tries to be angry with him... and cannot (this is a response, we'll find, that both MARTY and his UNCLE AL evoke). She smiles at him a little.
He reverses his wheelchair, also smiling a little, and leaves.

head_text.subj: EXT. TARKER'S MILLS, UNDER THE MOON NIGHT

text: We're looking down at a brave little nestle of lights. SOUND: A HOWL.

location: A HOUSE SOME DISTANCE OUT IN THE COUNTRY

text: There's one light on upstairs and another downstairs... a downstairs is the bluish flicker of TV light. An ivy trellis climbs one side of the house. SOUNDS: Canned laughter; TV dialogue.

location: THE LIVING ROOM OF THE RANDOLPH HOUSE

text: STELLA'S MOTHER, asleep in front of the TV.

A whole bunch of capsules are dumped into it. THE CAMERA DRAWS BACK to show us STELLA, sitting by her vanity mirror. The rest of the room is reflected in the mirror, including the window - we are upstairs. [NOTE: It would be nice to see that fat moon floating in window!] There's a framed picture of STELLA's ex-boyfriend on the vanity beside the dish of pills. STELLA sets down the emp prescription bottle the pills came from beside this pictu We can clearly read the word "Nembutol" on it. There is a a large glass of water on the vanity table. STELLA turns the picture facedown. She might be crying bu probably she's not. She takes about five of the pills, starts to lift them to her mouth- A HOWL outside... closer. STELLA looks around for a moment, then takes the pills wi some water. She pauses, looking at herself.
Suicides go to hell. Especially if they're pregnant. And I don't even care. She takes another five pills. And another five. SOUNDS: Rattling foliage.
Claw-hands are seizing it and climbing. SOUNDS of hoarse, guttural breathing.
She takes another handful of pills... and the window behi her shatters inward. There is a bellowing roar as the werewolf throws itself through.
She sits up, startled awake. From upstairs: ANOTHER SHATTERING ROAR... FOLLOWED BY A SCREAM.
She runs... and a huge claw-hand rips through the back of her nightgown.
Oh my dear God... Stella! She runs for the doorway and the hall. From upstairs come confusion of SOUNDS: roars, breaking furniture, shatterin glass.
One of those deadly claw-hands sweeps down the bed, rippi through the sheets... the mattress... the spring itself. Hairy, muddy feet with protruding talons leap onto it.
The werewolf leaps out - it's graceful, savage, animal. SOUND: A TRIUMPHANT HOWL.
She's found an ancient pistol somewhere and is lugging it gamely along.
Stella!...Stella! She reaches the closed door of STELLA's room, vacillates there for a moment... and then pushes it open and goes in A long beat of silence as we hold on the door. MOTHER SHRIEKS.
She shrieks again.

It's a total shambles; blood is splattered everywhere; th mirror is broken, the picture of DAN the gay deceiver is broken; the bed is torn in two. There are big, muddy wolfprints on the remnants of the bed. STELLA lies propped in the corner with Nembutols all arou her. Suicide may have been what she planned, but it sure isn't what happened. MOTHER SHRIEKS.

a.) MR. PELTZER puts out his paper rack - just the "Press-Herald" this morning. He looks shocked and grim. T scare headline: BRUTAL MURDER ROCKS WESTERN MAINE. We can see STELLA'S photograph. b.) Through the window of Robertson's Luncheonette, we se the proprietor, BOBBY ROBERTSON, talking earnestly with a bunch of men. Among them: MILT STURMFULLER, ALFIE KNOPFLE VIRGIL CUTTS, BILLY McCLAREN, and ELMER ZINNEMAN, a farme we'll meet later. c.) At Andy's Sporting Goods, ANDY FAIRTON is putting a b hand-lettered sign in the window. It reads: REMINGTON

head_text.subj: SHOTGUNS SINGLE ACTION DOUBLE ACTION PUMP PROTECT YOURSEL

text: d.) At the Methodist parsonage, a '53 Dodge pulls slowly and MOTHER RANDOLPH gets out, weeping. As she approaches parsonage door, LESTER LOWE comes out and embraces her.

location: A SMALL BRICK BUILDING ON MAIN STREET

text: The sign reads: TARKER'S MILLS TOWN OFFICE.

location: A HALLWAY, FEATURING A DOOR WITH A PEBBLED-GLASS PA

text: Neatly lettered on the panel: TARKER'S MILLS CONSTABULARY And below this: JOSEPH HALLER. JOE HALLER (voice) Okay...yes...Oh, fuck off!

location: THE CONSTABLE'S OFFICE, WITH HALLER AND PETE SYLVES

text: HALLER slams the phone down with an angry bang. He looks like a guy who has been up all night. PETE, his pudgy deputy, looks like a high school athlete who has suddenly found himself batting in the World Series.
What'd they say, Joe?

They said they'd be here by noon. PETE (nervous) Maybe it wasn't such a good idea telling that Smokey Bear from the Detective Division to fuck off, Joe. HALLER (morosely) I waited until he hung up. Jesus, what a mess. I wish I'd stayed in the army. Let's go on out there. He gets slowly up.

head_text.subj: EXT. TARKER'S MILLS CONSOLIDATED SCHOOL AFTERNOON

text: It's a comfortable red-brick building on a side street. I climbs up the sides. Two or three rows of bikes stand alo one side of the building. SOUND: The bell rings. A beat or two, then the doors bang wide and a billion kid spill out. It's the end of the first day of school, and t are excited. They range from Grade 1 to Grade 8. Most kid book it for home as fast as they can, getting on their bi and riding or just running. Everyone has a pink report card.

location: A BUNCH OF KIDS, WITH BRADY KINCAID AND TAMMY

text: BRADY and TAMMY are riding bikes. Now there is the SOUND a gasoline engine, and MARTY catches up. He's got the Sil Bullet's motor running for the first time in the movie. Later on it will sound extremely powerful, like a racing car, but now it just sounds like a big lawnmower engine w a muffler on it. It's pretty cool, though - a bright metallic silver with flame decals on the motor housing. Looks sort of like something Big Daddy Roth might have thought up. On the back is a license plate which says SIL BULLET.
Look out! Look out! It's Madman Marty and the Silver Bullet! TAMMY laughs.
You glad to be back in jail, Marty?
Sure - I like school.
You booger.
That's what my sister says, too. Pretty soon I'm going to start checking the mirror to see if I'm turning green.
I gotta split - see ya, Marty... Tammy.

TAMMY and MARTY watch as BRADY zooms off toward home on h bike. MARTY pushes in a hand clutch and moves a small lever. He bumps down over the curb and they cross the street side b side, TAMMY on her bike, MARTY in his wheelchair.

location: MARTY AND TAMMY FROM THE FAR CURB, REVERSE

text: He pops up over the curbing with a bounce. He shoves in t little hand clutch and revs the engine. Va-room!
Not bad, huh? My Uncle Al took off the regular muffler and put on a Cherry Bomb.
What's that?
Glasspack. He said he'd come over sometime this summer and we'd soup up the engine... but now I dunno. He's getting a divorce and he's in the doghouse with my mother.
For getting a divorce?
Well... it is his third.

location: A STREET ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF TOWN, WITH MARTY AND

text: The other kids are gone; they are alone. The sidewalk has ended and they roll slowly along the dirt verge of the ro They look toward:

The driveway is blocked off with a sawhorse bearing the stenciled words POLICE INVESTIGATION. The yard is filled with cop cars - HALLER'S constable car, plus a number of state police vehicles. Uniformed men come and go. We can see a large black wreath on the door.
Thanks for coming with me, Marty- I was scared to go past her house by myself. MARTY (matter-of-fact) Yeah... it is a little scary.
I mean, I saw her. All the time. TAMMY stops her bike. She's on the verge of tears.
I used to see her every day, and she never knew what was going to happen to her, and neither did I! I mean I know how stupid that sounds, but...
Hey, take it easy. I know how you feel. He gets the Silver Bullet moving again, and she has to pe along to catch up.

location: THE STURMFULLER DRIVEWAY, WITH MARTY AND TAMMY

text: They stop at the end.
There's something else scary.
What? TAMMY (points) That.

It stands a bit behind the house itself. A creepy place. Many of the glass panes are broken; some of these - not m - have been blocked with cardboard. The inside is a jungl of plants that have run to riot. In the f.g. is a mucky-looking garden patch where nothing much is growing.
She is quite deeply troubled.
I've been hearing noises in there.
What kind of noises?
Rattling. Rustling.
Rats...
And my dad says it's kids. But it's not rats and it's not kids. It's-

Oh my suds and body, here is the Great American Alcoholic for sure - the rural version. MILT is wearing a suit of pee-stained thermal underwear. He's wearing a baseball ca with the word "Caterpillar" on the front and has a bottle beer in one hand (I'm pretty sure that his beer is Rheing the dry beer). With his other hand he is busily scratchin his crotch.
Tammy, you get on in here and do some dishes!
Sinister...spooky. TAMMY (voice) I've got to go.
I'd go out and take a look myself, but I think the Bullet'd get stuck in the garden. It looks sorta greasy. She smiles at him, bends over, and kisses him on the mout MARTY is stunned... but happy.
You would, wouldn't you? MARTY (Joe Cool) Sure. No sweat.
Well, it's probably nothing. I'm just spooked since... you know.
Yeah... but if you hear any more noises, tell your father. Okay?
Okay. Have you got enough gas to get home, Marty? MARTY (Startled) Jeez!
There's a gas gauge here, and the needle is almost on "E.
I'm always doing this! I gotta go, Tammy. MILT (voice)
TAMMY (calls) Coming Daddy! (To MARTY) Bye... thanks again for coming home with me. She waves and goes biking down the driveway as MARTY moto back onto the street and turns toward town.
She brings her bike to a stop by her father.
'Bout time. Why you want to hang around that cripple?
I like him.

Goddamn cripples always end up on welfare. Ought to electrocute all of 'em. Balance the fucking budget. Having delivered this pearl of wisdom, MILT goes inside, scratching his ass. TAMMY pauses a moment and looks towar THE CAMERA, her face troubled and scared.
He's buzzing along toward downtown, which is still some distance away - but at least he's made it back to the sidewalk again. MARTY (prayerfully) Come on, baby- He looks down at:
Now the needle is lying all the way over on "E."
MARTY pulls in. The wheelchair motor starts to pop and lu and misfire. The chair makes it to the first pump on the island closest to the street and then stalls as VIRGIL CU comes over.
Well, Marty! I see you lucked out again!
Yep. Would you fill it up, please, Mr. Cutts?
Want me to check the oil?
Sure!
Wipe the windshield an check the driver's bullshit level? MARTY laughs; VIRGIL starts carefully pumping gas into th Silver Bullet's small tank.
Overhead is the moon, three days past the full. UNCLE AL (voice) I'll see your Carlton Fiske and raise you a George Brett... a Dave Kingman... and a Rod Carew.

head_text.subj: INT. THE KITCHEN DOORWAY, WITH NAN COSLAW NIGHT

text: She's wiping her hands with a dishtowel and looks like sh just bit into a lemon.

head_text.subj: INT. THE DEN, WITH UNCLE AL AND MARTY NIGHT

text: UNCLE AL is the family's sheep of a darker color. He's thirty, good-looking, raffish. He's also drunk. He's got both whiskey and beer. An ashtray beside him overflows wi butts. He and MARTY are playing draw poker for MARTY'S baseball cards. Each has a pile in front of him. MARTY really loves UNCLE AL... his eyes just glow when he looks at him.
Okay, okay. I call. He tosses in three baseball cards.
Wait a minute, wait a minute! He grabs one of MARTY'S cards, looks at it, and tosses it back.
Ralph Houk! You can't bet a manager! Stone the crows!
Okay, okay. Dwight Evans.
Piss on him. Piss on all the Red Sox. He swallows whiskey and chases it with beer.
NAN comes briskly over. She's seen and heard enough. She favors UNCLE AL with a glare and then looks protectively MARTY.
Come on, Marty- bedtime. She starts to wheel him away.
Mom-!
Let the boy finish the game, Nan. He means it, drunk or not. She reluctantly rolls MARTY ba to the table.
Make it quick. UNCLE AL lays down his hand.
Three kings. MARTY (delighted) I got a straight to the queen!
Bullshit luck! NAN (outraged) That's enough! MARTY (as his mother wheels him away) Aww, Mom-!

location: THE STAIRWELL OF THE COSLAW HOME

text: MARTY is sitting in a stair chair that rises slowly to th second floor. He looks dejected and glum. SOUND of NAN hectoring her brother AL. I don't think we c make out all of what's going on, but we've all known wome like NAN and I think we can fill in the blanks. "Christia household... you come here drunk and expect... can't even bother to call ahead..." Etc., etc. A wheelchair stands on the second-floor landing. This one no Silver Bullet, only the more humble sort that moves by arm power. When the stair chair clicks to a stop, MARTY hoists himself from it into the wheelchair and rolls down the hall toward the bathroom. Below, NAN'S rant is still going on.

head_text.subj: INT. THE DEN, WITH NAN AND UNCLE AL NIGHT

text: UNCLE AL is clearing up in a kind of drunken stupor- and mean he is really drunk. He's smoking one cigarette; anot is smoldering away in the heaping ashtray. He drops a pil of baseball cards on the floor and bonks his head on the table bending down to pick them up.

I don't want you drinking around Marty. That's too much. If you can't stop it, you better stay away. AL straightens up. There is a sort of command force in th man, and here he is partly able to rise above his abysmal drunkenness so we can see it.
I come here because Marty needs a friend.

Yes... you've always been that to him. But if you can't leave your booze in whatever dump you call home, you better just stay away. She leaves the room, almost crying. UNCLE AL looks after her, and then his attention is drawn to the smoldering ashtray. He pours beer over the mess, putting out the fir but creating something that looks even worse. He begins drunkenly picking up again. UNCLE AL (to himself) Another wonderful time at Sister Nan's house! Heeyyy!
MARTY, now in pj's, is brushing his teeth. JANE comes in- she's wearing a nightie.
Mom was really mad at him this time, wasn't she?
What do you expect, when he comes in smelling like a brewery and looking like an unmade bed?
Stop it! He lunges at her, but JANE steps back easily. MARTY overbalances and falls out of the wheelchair. His toothbr clatters across the tile. BOB COSLAW (sleepy voice) Hey! That you, Marty?
He's okay, Dad! She looks around swiftly, then bends down.
One of MARTY'S cheeks is pressed against the floor. His e are shut. He's weeping. JANE (low) Marty, are you all right?
Yes. Go away.

Let me help you up. NAN (voice) Marty? SOUND of her climbing the stairs. JANE throws a quick look back over her shoulder and then helps MARTY up in his chair. He helps by pulling on the s counter. JANE has time to give MARTY one quick look- "Ple don't tell on me," it says. NAN comes in.
Jane, have you been teasing your brother again?

She wasn't, Mom- I dropped my toothbrush and fell over when I tried to get it. Jane helped pick me up. He bats his eyes at her. MARTY (syrupy voice) Jane's wunnnderful. JANE picks up his toothbrush. JANE (hands it to him) Here. Brush them good, Marty. Some of that shit in your head might leak down into your mouth and poison you.
Jane Coslaw! But JANE stalks off. MARTY is grinning. It was a good put-down.
We can see the moon in the sky beyond the ruined greenhou THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY TOWARD the greenhouse. We begin t pick up SOUNDS: RATTLING...RUSTLING...and low animal GRUN
She's deeply asleep.

"Big-time Wrestling" on the TV. SOUND of a refrigerator d closing. MILT STURMFULLER comes into the living room from the kitchen. He's wearing his long johns with the designe pee stains and has a quart bottle of Rheingold the dry be in each hand. He sits down, looking at the TV. MILT (drunk) Give him the airplane! Wring his neck!
More noises. There is a beat of silence, and then somethi one of those earthen plant pots, I think- falls over and SHATTERS.
He looks up briefly- he's heard something- but the crowd the TV is loud and the match is reaching its climax. MILT (all eyes again) Give him the sleeper, you fuckin bugwit!
A LOW SNARL. Plants shake and shiver. Another crash, LOUD
Looks toward the window. He gets up, goes over, and looks out.
SOUND of another crash. Plants move.
He takes a shotgun from the wall, breaks it, and looks inside.
Let's see if you want to come back and break my pots all to shit after I put some rock salt in your asses!

The door at the end SCREECHES OPEN and MILT, still holdin the shotgun at port arms, comes cautiously in. This place really overgrown. MILT advances slowly into the jungle of plants, and the director will shoot it as he likes to build the suspense. I'm sure that plants brush his face, and a bug or two- ma even a big plump spider- will land on him. He hears a SCUTTERING SOUND and whirls. MILT (shouts) Who's there?
A mouse goes running across the warped boards (which have pulled apart from each other, showing deep cracks between

He relaxes and starts forward again. We keep expecting it happen, but it keeps not happening. Then, as MILT is starting back toward the door, two big, hairy arms come up through the floor- bursting through tw of those cracks and shoving the splintered boards upward- and grab MILT'S legs at the knees. SOUNDS: BESTIAL ROARS. MILT screams and triggers off the shotgun- unfortunately, is pointing straight up. Glass showers down on him. He is pulled down into the shattered hole- now we can see him o from the knees up.
She sits up in bed. SOUNDS of ROARS and MILT SCREAMING from the greenhouse. MRS. STURMFULLER, in a nightgown with her hair done up in rollers, comes into Tammy's room.
Tammy, where's your father? SOUND: Another SCREAM from the greenhouse.

He's now waist deep in the hole in the floor, surrounded broken, splintered boards. SOUNDS: RIPPING FLESH, CRUNCHING BONES. MILT SHRIEKS. He is abruptly jerked downward again. He is being eaten f the feet up. As he's jerked down, one of the leaning, splintered boards rams into his chest. MILT collapses ove it like an old Roman collapsing on his sword. A hairy arm reaches up and grabs his neck. MILT is jerked all the way into the hole, board and all.

location: THE GREENHOUSE, FROM TAMMY'S BEDROOM WINDOW

text: SOUNDS of SNARLS, GROWLS, GRUNTS.
They are hugging each other, terrified, by the window.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE STURMFULLER PLACE, MEDIUM-LONG DAY

text: The police cars are now here. There's also a meat wagon. we watch, a number of cops- JOE HALLER and PETE SYLVESTER are among them- approach the wagon. Many are carrying can bags.

location: THE STURMFULLER YARD, FEATURING PETE SYLVESTER

text: He drops the blood stained bag he's carrying, runs to the bushes, and noisily blows his groceries.

a.) On Oak Street, MRS. THAYER is hurrying toward home, obviously spooked. She keeps looking behind herself and nearly flies up the steps to her house. Then there is the endless business of fumbling with her keys. Finally she lurches inside and slams the door. b.) On Main Street, at the Holy Family rectory, FATHER O'BANION is closing the shutters...and locking them. c.) On a residential street, a kid is playing with some plastic trucks outside of a picket fence. Except for him, the street is deserted. His mother comes out and hauls hi in. d.) ANDY FAIRTON, in the sporting-goods store, checks an automatic pistol and then holsters it on his hip. He has pugnacious, unpleasant look. e.) BILLY McCLAREN turns the sign on the door of his barb shop from OPEN to CLOSED, looks out warily at the street make sure there are no psycho killers out there for trims guess), then leaves and locks the door behind him. THE CAMERA FOLLOWS him down a couple of store fronts to Owen' where he also goes in. f.) The paper rack in front of Peltzer's Drug/ The "Press-Herald" headline is a sixteen-pointer: MANIAC CLAI SECOND VICTIM.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARTY AND BRADY KINCAID MAGIC HOUR

text: They're flying kites on the common. Some distance in the b.g. is the bandstand. MARTY is of course flying his kite he sits in the Silver Bullet. The boys are having a blast THE CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES AWAY from the boys, centers on Owen's Pub across the street, and ZOOMS IN. In the window is a poster. It reads: $10,000 REWARD FOR

head_text.subj: INFORMATION LEADING TO THE CAPTURE OF THE MAN, (OR ANIMAL)

text: WHO KILLED STELLA RANDOLPH AND MILTON STURMFULLER. And, a the bottom: TARKER'S MILLS CITIZENS' COMMITTEE. Along comes ANDY FAIRTON. He goes into the pub.

At a f.g. table: VIRGIL CUTTS, BOBBY ROBERTSON, ELMER ZINNEMAN, and his brother PORTER ZINNEMAN. Behind them, a the bar, we see PETE SYLVESTER having a beer with BILLY McCLAREN. As we look around the bar, we will also see FAT LESTER LOWE, sitting at an unobtrusive corner table, nurs a beer and listening closely to the conversation. ELMER (to VIRGIL) Don't tell me an animal can't rip a man up the way Milt Sturmfuller was ripped up!
But the woman's bed was ripped right down the middle, Elmer- it's take a chainsaw to do something like that!
Damn straight!
Shut up, Porter. (To VIRGIL) What about the tracks? ANDY FAIRTON has joined the group. He sits down uninvited
That could be something to throw off the cops. And it ain't animals that try to confues the law; it's people do that.

Law around here don't need much confusing. PETE looks around at this. Being the deputy constable and ineffectual by nature, he's pretty sensitive. ANDY (deep disgust) Joe Haller couldn't find his own ass if someone rammed it full of radium and gave him a Geiger counter. PETE SYLVESTER (comes over) Could be I know a fella who's still PO'd over getting fined two hundred bucks for that little fender bender out on the Ridge Road last year.

Could be I know a fat old fella who ought to take care of his mouth before someone comes along and turns it inside out. I pay Joe Haller's salary to keep the people in this town safe, and he ain't doing it. INT.  BILLY McCLAREN, AT THE BAR He's looking toward the table where the Fairton group sit BILLY (mildly) Last town report said you was in arrears your taxes, Andy. Guess you must have paid up, huh?
What are you, trying to be smart? OWEN KNOPFLER comes over.
You guys turn down the thermostat or I'm gonna turn you all out. Now who's drinking? ANDY (sulks) Bring me a Schlitz.

head_text.subj: EXT. A TREE, WITH BRADY'S SMILE-KITE STUCK IN IT DUSK

text: SOUND of panting. MARTY comes into the frame, pulling himself up by the arm His arms are very strong, although his legs trail limply behind him (like the tail of a kite). He sits on a branch untangles the kite and the string, and looks down. MARTY (calls) Here it comes!

location: THE FOOT OF THE TREE, WITH BRADY

text: Drop it! As the kite flutters down, JANE comes biking up.
Marty Coslaw, you get down out of that tree!
He descends, then hangs from the lowest branch.
Push the Bullet over, Jane, okay?
JANE (makes no immediate move to do so) Supper was an hour ago, Dumbo. MARTY (hanging) Oh, Jeez! I forgot! Is she mad?
They both are. At me, for not getting you sooner. I ought to let you fall. But she pushes the chair over and MARTY drops into it. He pushes the starter and the Silver Bullet fires up.

head_text.subj: EXT. BRADY, FLYING HIS KITE ON THE COMMON DUSK

text: MARTY (voice) Hey, Brady! You coming? BRADY (looking into the sky) In a while! BRADY could give a shit if MARTY'S in trouble. He just wa vaguely. He's into the kite-flying experience, as the fol in Marin County might say.
He's looking toward the common, frowning and uncertain.
Come on, Marty. She starts biking away. MARTY starts after her, pauses, a looks at:

head_text.subj: EXT. BRADY, ON THE COMMON DUSK

text: CAMERA PANS SLOWLY UP to the yellow smile-kite in the bluish-purple sky.

The former patrons are still here, with the exceptions of LOWE, BILLY McCLAREN, and BOBBY ROBERTSON. Many others ha appeared; this is Happy Hour. Among them we see MR. ASPINALL, the principal, and PELTZER, the druggist. A barmaid, NORMA, circulates with drinks and beers. Speaking of beer, ANDY FAIRTON has gotten through a fair amount of Schlitz. It hasn't mellowed him, however; he's more belligerent than ever. ANDY (holding forth) This whole investigation has been as efficient as a Polish fire drill! It- PETE (bravely) I've heard enough out of you, Andy. If you don't shut your mouth, I'm going to shut it for you.

head_text.subj: INT. THE DOOR OF OWEN'S PLACE

text: It opens and a man in a business suit- HERB KINCAID- come in. He is carrying a briefcase and he looks worried.

location: THE GROUP AT THE FAIRTON TABLE

text: ANDY (astounded) What did you say?

Jesus wept. He reaches under the bar and comes out with a baseball ba Burned into the side of the bat, so it reads vertically toward the handle, is the word "peacemaker." OWEN hurries around the bar with it.
PETE is standing in front of ANDY, fists balled up, fat f trembling with determination.

You heard what I said, motormouth. ANDY gets up, infuriated. There's apparently going to be brawl. Behind them, HERB KINCAID has approached the table HERB hasn't even noticed what's going on; he's got proble of his own.

He clears his throat. This is a mild, timid man- he doesn like to speak in public, particularly not in a bar, but t imperatives of the situation demand it right now. HERB (quite loudly) Has anyone in here seen my son Brady?

Everyone looks at HERB. Conversation stops. ANDY and PETE freeze with their fists balled up, like little kids playi statues tag. OWEN is caught a little distance from ANDY a PETE, with the "peacemaker" still in his hands.
Now it is almost completely dark, and a large reddish sum moon is rising over the horizon. SOUND: A LONG, WAVERING WOLF HOWL... LOUD.
All conversation has stopped. All have turned toward the door and the windows; all hear the HOWL. Deep fright overlies each face. NORMA drops her tray. Glasses and bottles shatter.

location: THE MAIN CORRIDOR OF THE TOWN HALL

text: JOE HALLER comes out of the constable's office in a hurry letting the door bang the wall. He's buckling on his gun belt.
BRADY'S kite, torn in a couple of places, flutters on the steps leading up to the bandstand. The yellow smile face grins eerily in the darkness. It is streaked with blood.
Brady! He breaks for the door. ANDY FAIRTON grabs him.
Get out of my way! He pushes ANDY aside. HERB is out the door, chased by PET and several of the others.

JOE HALLER (low voice) Hail Mary, full of grace, the Lord is with thee. Blessed art thou among women... He comes out of the shadows, his drawn gun dangling by hi side. This man has had an extremely bad shock. The legs o his uniform pants are splashed with blood. He makes it do two steps and then sits heavily by the remains of BRADY'S smiling, bloody kite. He looks straight ahead. He looks a nothing. HALLER (low) ...and blessed is the fruit of Thy womb. Jesus. Holy Mary, Mother of God, pray for us sinners now...now... He looks at the kite, then looks away. He puts a hand ove his face and starts to cry.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE COMMON, LOOKING BACK TOWARD MAIN STREET NIGHT

text: A number of men - not all that were in Owen's but quite a few of them - are running toward the bandstand. HERB KINC is in the lead, screaming his son's name over and over. SOUND: A LONG HOWL, now at some distance.

location: THE BANDSTAND, WITH HALLER AND KINCAID

text: As HERB KINCAID approaches.
Stay off the bandstand, Herb.
Is it my boy? Is it Brady?
Don't go up- HERB (lunges past him) Brady! Brady! Disappears into the dark. HALLER looks down at his lap.
Br-(CUTS OFF) The other men arrive, PETE in the lead. HALLER doesn't lo up.
Joe, is it- HALLER (not looking up) Shhh.
Is it the Kicaid b- HALLER (not looking up) Shhh, I said. The men look uneasily at HALLER, at each other. ANDY FAIR shoves forward.

What the fuck is going on h- SOUND: HERB SCREAMS. A pause. HERB screams again. The men flinch back. HALLER doesn't look up. Now, from the darkne on the bandstand, HERB begins to LAUGH. The men shrink ba further, looking more uneasy than ever. HERB (voice; laughing) We'll bury his shoes. Now HALLER gets up and joins the other men. HERB (voice; laughing) That's what we'll have to do; we'll bury his shoes. Maybe in a couple of Roi-Tan cigar boxes.
HERB KINCAID appears. He is laughing. He is smeared with son's blood. In each hand he holds one of his son's shoes
We'll bury his shoes because his feet are still in them and they're the only part of him that makes sense anymore. HERB laughs harder.
It's gonna be the cheapest funeral this town ever saw!

SOUND: An organ is playing that sweet old hymn, "Bringing The Sheaves." There are lots of cars parked in front of the church, but there's a space left just big enough for UNCLE AL'S MG. MARTY'S Silver Bullet is strapped to the back. JANE (v-o) My mother and father- my mother in particular- did not much care for Uncle Al...

MARTY'S chair is at the back of the church. Most of the mourners are crying. MRS. BOWIE is playing the organ. BRADY'S coffin is on a bier at the front - closed of cour There are lots of flowers. JANE (v-o continues) ...but when it came to such unpleasant duties as taking Marty to the funeral of his best friend...

location: UNCLE AL, MARTY, TAMMY, AND MRS. STURMFULLER IN A P

text: As we look at them, from left to right: UNCLE AL, MARTY, TAMMY, MRS. STURMFULLER. UNCLE AL unobtrusively takes a small silver flask from hi hip pocket. Engraved on it in Old English letters is the word "rotgut." He spins the cap and takes a quick knock. pauses and glances at MARTY, who looks deeply stunned. JANE (v-o continues) ...they didn't at all mind drafting him. As to the sort of comfort Uncle Al may have been able to offer him... UNCLE AL hands the flask to MARTY. MARTY looks at him questioningly for a moment, and then drinks. MARTY looks TAMMY, who looks frankly terrible. Her mother is looking away. MARTY nudges her. She looks around at him. He offer her the flask. Her eyes widen. JANE (v-o continues) ...I now believe that was best kept between the two of them... After a brief moment's consideration, TAMMY takes the fla and has a deep swallow. She hands the flask back to MARTY who hands it quickly back to UNCLE AL as TAMMY coughs. He mother looks at her... then at MARTY and UNCLE AL. UNCLE smiles sympathetically, hiding the flask with one hand, a if to say, "Isn't it a terrible thing?" MRS. STURMFULLER looks distractedly back toward the service. JANE (v-o concludes) ...or among the three of them. UNCLE AL pockets the flask just as the organ stops playin

Mr. and Mrs. Kincaid have asked that there be no mass said here this afternoon. There will be a requiem mass for Brady Kincaid this Sunday. They did ask me to say a word of comfort to you, if I could. He looks out at them.
They look back at LOWE, hoping for some help in understanding this awful thing.
If there is any word of comfort I can give you, it's just this: the face of the beast always becomes known; the time of the beast always passes. He is struggling with this, trying dreadfully hard.

If there are times when we feel alone and afraid, only small creatures in the dark, then these are the times when we must turn to one another for our comfort and our hope. To our neighbors. To our community. To our love for each other. I alone cannot ease the pain for Herb and Naomi Kincaid, nor can I ease your pain, nor you ease mine. But if I believe anything it's this: we can comfort each other. We can heal each other. We can go on together.

location: THE CONGREGATION, WITH MARTY AND TAMMY

text: The kids are crying. MARTY puts an arm around TAMMY and s puts her head on his shoulder.

The Bible tells us not to fear the terror that creepeth by night or that which flieth by noonday, and yet we do... we do. Because there is much we don't know, and we feel very small. But we must not be alone. We must not allow ourselves to be alone, for there is the wide gate to the hell of terror. Turn to each other. Join hands in your sorrow and try to remember that the face of the beast always becomes known. (Pause) The time of the beast always passes. (Pause) Let us pray.
MARTY and TAMMY look at each other miserably. TAMMY begin to cry- for her father as much as for BRADY, one would think- and she and MARTY embrace.
He looks at the kids with deep sympathy and deep love.
UNCLE AL'S sports car passes THE CAMERA. He's taking MART home.

location: THE CAR, WITH MARTY AND UNCLE AL

text: You all right, Marty?
Yeah.
There's a saying- so-and-so was better than a poke in the eye with a sharp stick. You ever hear that one?
No.
Well, I'm not sure that was. Christ! They better get the guy.
Uncle Al, what if it's not a guy?
Huh?
What if it's some kind of monster? UNCLE AL (laughs) Jesus, Marty! Come off it!

location: UNCLE AL'S CAR, ON MAIN STREET

text: It cruises past Owen's Pub. There are cars parked out fro but there are also lots of pickup trucks.

location: THE CAR, WITH MARTY AND UNCLE AL

text: What's going on at Owen's, Uncle Al?
A bunch of men getting ready to pretend they're Clint Eastwood... Marty, didn't anybody ever tell you that the only monsters are in comic books and drive-in movies?

head_text.subj: EXT. THE COSLAW HOUSE LATE AFTERNOON

text: UNCLE AL'S car turns in and parks.

location: THE CAR, WITH MARTY AND UNCLE AL

text: Tammy said she'd been hearing noises in that greenhouse. Growling noises, like a big animal. Her father was killed that night. UNCLE AL looks at him doubtfully for a moment, as if almo believing. Then he shakes his head.

Marty, you have to get this idea out of your head. Psychotics are more active when the moon is full, and this guy is a psycho. He's going to turn out to be as human as you or me. (Pause) In a manner of speaking. Now let's get you inside. He opens his door and gets out.
He would like to believe UNCLE AL... but he doesn't.
Okay, you all know what group you're in and what area you'll be covering, right?
Damn straight!

Shut up, Porter. The men are all dressed in hunting clothes- red-and-black-checked shirts, orange caps, etc. They all have guns. Among their number are a few women as well, looking tough and determined. We see almost everyone we'v met up to this point. LOWE is there, looking deeply troubled. ANDY FAIRTON is standing on the bar. These are his vigilantes; he has organized them. ANDY radiates male mac football-coach confidence. He's mesmerized the crowd: the really believe they are going to go out and Shoot One for the Gipper.

Groups one through four are in the woods north of the Sturmfuller place. Five and six west of Carson Creek. The door at the back opens; HALLER and PETE come in. JOE HALLER is in extremely bad shape. He hasn't come back muc from the murder of BRADY. I believe he is having some sor of spiritual crisis, and while it is not our purpose to explore what it might be- this is, after all, a horror mo and not a John Cassavetes film- we can see that it has seriously weakened his authority. ANDY (continuing) Moonrise at 8:52 p.m. Some nervous laughter greets this. Meanwhile, HALLER and PETE are working their way to the front, where they end u next to a grim-faced HERB KINCAID. ANDY (continuing) If he comes out to stroll in the moonlight tonight, we're going to get the sorry sucker.

location: THE VIGILANTES, WITH ELMER AND PORTER

text: PORTER (happily) Damn straight!
Shut up, Porter.
Just remember, it's the psycho we want, not each other. So look before you-
I want all of you folks to go home! A disgruntled murmur meets this. HALLER moves forward a b and turns to face them.
I can't remember deputizing a single one of you!
That's right, Joe- the only deputy you got is that fat shitbag beside you, and neither one of you has done a damn thing about solving this case. There is a mutter of agreement.

ANDY hops off the bar to face HALLER directly. In the b.g we see HERB KINCAID (KINCAID, by the way, should be weari a black armband- he's come directly from his son's funera HALLER (without much force) We'll catch him.

You couldn't catch a cold. HALLER looks at him for a moment, then turns to look at t crowd. They look rather like a lynch mob; on their faces see an uneasy mix of shame and eager determination. HALLE speaks with a kind of haggard, fading desperation.

The law has a name for what you men are planning. It's private justice, and private justice is about a step and a half away from lynch mobs and hang ropes. I'm no J. Edgar Hoover, but I am the law in Tarker's Mills, and I want you men to go home. They shuffle their feet uneasily; many look down. He is getting to them.

Don't let this guy scare you! What's he done since this thing started but hang his face out? It's not working. Many of the men look disgusted with bot ANDY and themselves. ANDY (louder) He ain't got so much as a fingerprint!
Ah, shut up, Andy.
Don't tell me to- HERB KINCAID steps forward.
Yes. Correct. Shut up. ANDY, surprised and bewildered, does. HERB turns and look grimly at JOE HALLER, who can barely meet his gaze. HERB (quietly) I just came from my boy's funeral.
Herb...I know how upset- how grief-stricken you must be...but- HERB (quietly) He was torn apart. Utter silence in OWEN'S place now. The others are staring rapt.

Yes. Yes, but- HERB (still quiet) Upset, you say. Grief-stricken, you say. Constable, you don't know what those words mean. My son was torn to pieces. To pieces! HERB turns to the others in the pub. Tears stream down hi face.

My son was torn to pieces! (turning back to HALLER) You come in here and talk to these men about private justice. You dare to do that. Constable Haller, why don't you go out to Harmony Hill and dig up what's left of Brady and explain to him about private justice. Would you want to do that? HALLER makes no reply. He looks down at his feet.

No. I thought not. (to the others) You folks stay here if you want. I wouldn't ask anyone to do anything that runs counter to his conscience. As for me... I'm going out and hunt up a little private justice. ANDY FAIRTON has swelled up again. He grins poisonously a the slumped HALLER. He pushes off after HERB KINCAID. Oth men start to follow.

Men are streaming out, getting into station wagons and pickup trucks. Engines roar into life. They begin backing out even as more men come out of the pub. We even hear so high-spirited yells; they are on their way and their bloo is up.
LESTER LOWE, looking more distressed than ever, pushes hi way through the men toward the door, and THE CAMERA FOLLO He grabs BILLY McCLAREN.

Billy... Billy, this is a bad idea. Joe can... BILLY (not looking at LOWE) Joe's had his chance, Father. Leave me be. He pushes outside. LOWE looks around wildly; his face say he can't believe this is happening. He grabs PORTER ZINNEMAN, then, as PORTER shoves by him, at a couple of others with mounting desperation. HALLER makes his way to LOWE through the thinning crowd a draws him aside.
Let them go.
But-

This is that spirit of community you were talking about. Grand, ain't it? Maybe they'll shoot a hitchhiker or something and Andy can mount the head and raffle it off. To benefit the Medcu van, of course. HALLER laughs.
But can't we do anything? OWEN KNOPFLER hurries past them; he has a rifle over one shoulder in a sling. In his left hand he carries the peacemaker bat.
Sure. We can pray to Christ that none of them get killed.

More cars and trucks pull away. There's a big old Ford "woody" wagon still there, with ANDY FAIRTON standing impatiently by the driver's side door. BILLY McCLAREN and BOBBY ROBERTSON are with him, and a big, solid-looking wo named MAGGIE ANDREWS. OWEN comes out and crosses to the woody.

Well, it's about frigging time! They'll have his hide tacked to somebody's barn door before we get out there! They pile into the car, ANDY behind the wheel. He throws into gear and backs out onto Main Street.
We see a parade of cars and pickup trucks headed out of town.
He's standing on the curb and watching them leave town in procession, some honking their horns, others yelling cheerfully. The expression on his face is dark and broodi

head_text.subj: EXT. THE FULL MOON, CU NIGHT
EXT. ELMER AND PORTER ZINNEMAN NIGHT

text: ELMER is lying on his belly, stuck halfway under a barbed-wire fence. The seat of his pants is badly snagged The brothers are on the verge of a wooded area. We can se ground mist creeping around the bottoms of the trees.
Help me Porter, goddammit! PORTER grabs ELMER'S right arm and pulls. There's a RIPPI SOUND. ELMER screams.
Don't pull me! You want to rip the right cheek of my ass right off?
Well, Elmer, there are folks that'd say you've been half-assed most of your-
Are you going to unhook me or be a wise guy? PORTER begins to pick the barbed wire out of ELMER'S pant

location: IN THE WOODS, WITH REV. O'BANION AND VIRGIL CUTTS

text: O'BANION looks rather amusing in his hunting gear- like t priest from "The Exorcist" on safari.
Jesus, that was close. Uh, pardon me, Rev'runt.

Come on. Be careful. They move slowly ahead, O'BANION still a bit in the lead. THE CAMERA FOLLOWS as the reverend pushes into some knee-high brush. SOUND: A RUSTY METALLIC CLANG, followed by a FLESHY CHOMP O'BANION begins to scream and struggle.
Rev'runt! What is it? O'BANION (screaming) My foot! My foot! VIRGIL lunges to him and looks down.
A medium-sized trap- something in which one might reasona catch a wild cat or a coydog, let us say- has its rusty teeth sunk deeply into the reverend's ankle.
Get it off me! Get it off me! VIRGIL (flustered) Sure...okay... He kneels down.
He muscles the trap open, a little at a time.
Relaxing. SOUND: THE WOLF HOWLING CLOSE.
Startled and unnerved by the HOWL, the trap slips out of hands and snaps shut on O'BANION'S mangled ankle again.
He screams.
It slides behind a cloud. SOUND: THE WOLF HOWLING.

ANDY, BILLY McCLAREN, BOBBY ROBERTSON, OWEN KNOPFLER, and MAGGIE ANDREWS have been joined by two other men- MR. ASPINALL and EDGAR ROUNDS. They have drawn close together, listening as the HOWL FAD We can tell by their uneasy faces that some of the joy ha gone out of the evening. They are standing on one side of a ravine. The bottom is filled with a still ground mist. A few bushes poke out of it. There are woods on the far side. ANDY (pointing across) It came from over there.
As far as I could tell, it could have come from anywhere.
We'll spread out in a skirmish line. If the bastard tries to go around us, we'll hear him.
I dunno-

I think Bobby Robertson here's making lemonade in his pants. That lemonade got ice cubes in it, Bobby? ANDY FAIRTON and EDGAR ROUNDS laugh. ASPINALL and BILLY McCLAREN smile a little. OWEN (quietly) Let off him, Maggie. I'm scared, too. BOBBY (stoutly) I ain't scared! Let's go!
Okay. Spread out on me. Five feet apart.

location: ANDY'S GROUP, FROM THE BOTTOM OF THE RAVINE

text: Reading from right to left: OWEN KNOPFLER (his gun is sti over his shoulder; it is the peacemaker baseball bat he i holding), BOBBY ROBERTSON, ASPINALL, ANDY FAIRTON, BILLY McCLAREN, EDGAR ROUNDS and MAGGIE ANDREWS. They come slowly down toward THE CAMERA, alert and ready anything- at least, they think so.

They reach the bottom of the ravine and begin to make the way across it. The mist is waist to chest deep. They push toward the other side. Now they are about halfway. SOUND: A STEADY, LOW GROWLING, CLOSE. They all stop, scared. BILLY McCLAREN Where's it coming from? Other side?
No- it's behind us. I told you you couldn't trust-
It isn't on either side.
What are you- ASPINALL is looking around, his eyes widening with fear.
It's under the fog. It's right in with us. The GROWLING STOPS. There's a beat of silence. Then: SOUND: SNARLING...AND A RIPPING CHOMP as dinner is served SOUND: A SCREAM.

He's the one screaming, and if he reminds us of O'BANION, that's okay, because ROUNDS has also been caught in a tra He tries to run, stumbles, falls into the ground fog. He goes on screaming. We can see his back for a moment, and then it disappears. SOUNDS OF CRUNCHING AND SCREAMING. ROUNDS SHRIEKS. His hand and arm come up like the hand of drowning man. Then it's gone. ROUNDS is gone.
They stand there, chest deep in mist, a conspicuous hole the ranks where EDGAR was.
BOBBY (moaning) I can't move. Christ Jesus, I can't move!
The GROWLING STARTS AGAIN. THE CAMERA PANS SLOWLY UP THE LINE. The mist swirls, hiding whatever's beneath.

ASPINALL (low) I think we better start backing up, Andy. Real slow. Real- The LOW GROWL rises to a snarl. And from below the mist, snarling and bestial but understandable, mocking ASPINALL voice: WEREWOLF (voice) "Real slow! Real slow! Real slow!"

ASPINALL SHRIEKS and tries to run. He falls into the mist There is another CHOMP. When he flounders up, half his fa is gone. WEREWOLF (voice) "Real slow! Real slow!" A hairy arm rises from the mist and yanks ASPINALL down.
They panic and break for it- MAGGIE, BILLY, and ANDY for side, BOBBY and OWEN for the other.
THE CAMERA IS RUSHING THROUGH THE GROUND MIST- this is li being in an airplane that's skimming the top of a cloud. WEREWOLF (voice; laughing) "Real slow! Real slow! Real slow!"
He's hit, as an unlucky swimmer might be hit by a shark. whirls around, raising the peacemaker bat.
Come on, then! You want to rock and roll with me?
For a moment there's nothing- and then the werewolf rises out of it, eyes glaring green, muzzle and pelt slimed wit gore.
MAGGIE (shrieking) Look at it! Holy God, Andy, look at that thing! ANDY (groaning with fear) I don't want to look at it. He runs, while MAGGIE stares, mesmerized, at:
The WEREWOLF closes in on OWEN, who belts it a good one w the peacemaker. The WEREWOLF swipes at him. OWEN ducks an slams it again. The WEREWOLF roars with anger.

Come on, come on! You want to do the bop? I'll bop you, motherfucker! Come on! The WEREWOLF dives under the ground mist. Uncertain, OWEN begins to back up, holding the bat in his hands. OWEN is jerked down into the mist. He SCREAMS. The peacemaker rises out of the ground mist and comes down. Bonk! The WEREWOLF roars in pain. CHOMPING SOUND. OWEN shrieks. OWEN (voice) Come on, you bastard! The peacemaker rises out of the mist again. The hands holding it are bloody. Blood runs down the bat. It descen Bonk! The WEREWOLF roars again. There is a GURGLING SCREA from OWEN... and then a curious SPLINTERING SOUND as the WEREWOLF sinks its fangs into the bat.

THE CAMERA MOVES ABOVE as the WEREWOLF moves below, escap down the draw. Pause. SOUND, IN THE B.G.- low but slowly getting louder: congregation singing "Bringing In the Sheaves" to the accompaniment of a pipe organ. WEREWOLF (sing-songy voice) Bringing in the sheaves... bringing in the sheaves... we shall come rejoicing... bringing in the sheaves... THE WEREWOLF FADES OUT; human voices singing the same hym overwhelm it and we

It's an almost exact reprise of #167. Most of the mourner are crying; MRS. BOWIE playing the organ; MARTY'S chair parked at the back. We can see UNCLE AL, MARTY, TAMMY, an MRS. STURMFULLER, exactly as they were at BRADY KINCAID'S funeral; in fact, this seems to be an instant reply of th event. One difference: we can't see BRADY'S coffin. It's below us. The hymn ends.
Mr. and Mrs. Kincaid have asked that there be no mass said here this afternoon. They did ask me to say a word of comfort to you if I could.
He sits in the first pew. In his grief he looks dead.
There is no comfort, Father. Only private justice.
He's thrown off his stride. Beginning to sweat. He's like actor trying to remember his lines.
Uh, if there's any word of comfort I can give you, it's just this: the face of the beast always becomes known; the time- He looks down. His eyes widen in fear.
Yes, that's coffins- plural. Where BRADY'S coffin was formerly, there are now six coffins, smothered with flowe
He is badly scared now; sweat is dripping off him.
The time... the time of the beast always passes. There are answers... ways... ways to... to cope... if we turn to each other... HERB (bestial voice) Father- LOWE looks toward:

He's looking down at something in his hands. Now he looks and we see his face has become bestial. His eyes are gree As we look at him, the transformation cotinues. He's turn into a werewolf. HERB (snarling) It tore out his heart. And sure enough, HERB KINCAID holds BRADY'S dripping hear up in what were hands but which are now rapidly becoming paws.
He staggers back, in terror. LOWE (shrieks) No!
MRS. BOWIE begins bringing in a few more sheaves on the church organ, and the congregation begins to sing.

Sowing in the morning/sowing seeds of kindness/sowing in the noontide/and the dewy eve... We pan their faces, stopping on JOE HALLER. Now something happening to JOE'S face. It is bulging, changing. He look up from his hymnal and his eyes glare green. The pupils a split. He grins, showing big teeth. They are all changing. Among the things we see are: PETE SYLVESTER, who is a church deacon, rushing down the aisle, changing, snarling. He grabs ANDY FAIRTON and the of them grapple in the aisle. A YOUNG WOMAN with a baby in her arms turns back the blan covering the baby's face and we see it's a wolfling; alre the YOUNG WOMAN'S own hands are turning into claws. TAMMY STURMFULLER changing; PELTZER the druggist changing the ZINNEMAN BROTHERS changing. At the organ, MRS. BOWIE is now a werewolf clad in tatter of a silk bombazine dress; she/it is still wearing a veil hat on her head, and she is beating the shit out of the organ keys with her clawed hands. She sounds like Jerry L Lewis after swallowing about a dozen bennies. And now the tune changes from the remnants of "Bringing In The Sheave It changes into the Rheingold jingle. CONGREGATION (snarling chorus) My beer is Rheingold the dry beer... Think of Rheingold whenever you buy beer...
FATHER LOWE goes stumbling backward, dropping his hymnal. The man is in an extremity of terror.
No! No! No!

Some are tearing their hymnals apart and throwing them at each other. One guy- BILLY McCLAREN, maybe- wings one of them through a stained-glass window. Some of the werewolv for they are all werewolves now- fight or make love in th aisles. The rest sway back and forth, grinning ferociousl singing. CONGREGATION (snarling it out) It's not bitter, not sweet, it's a real frosty treat...
He looks toward:

location: THE MRS. BOWIE WEREWOLF, AT THE ORGAN

text: She grins ferociously up at him, playing the Rheingold jingle on the pipe organ with her claws. Now blood begins bubble up between the keys.
Won't you try, won't you buy...

The church is a wild shambles of lurching, fighting, sing werewolves. It's like a New Year's Eve party in hell. CONGREGATION (big finish) ...Rheiinngold beer! Suddenly a clawed hand burts up through one of the coffin And ANDY FAIRTON, who now looks as wolflike as any of the bites the hand's claw off.

He's seen all he can stand. He whirls for the back, where there is a small door. He pulls it open... and a BRADY KINCAID werewolf, half torn apart but still somehow alive zombie werewolf, if you can dig it- George Romero would l it, I think) leaps out and seizes LOWE. BRADY buries his muzzle in LOWE'S NECK.

He sits up into THE CAMERA and SCREAMS. Sweat is running down his face. He stares at us for a moment, his eyes bug and crazed... and then he closes them. There is an expression of huge relief on his face as he does so. LOWE (praying) Let it end, dear Lord. Let it end. Please let it end.
An old sedan cruises slowly down the street. ANNE and TAM STURMFULLER are in the front seat. It's piled high with possessions and is towing a jackleg trailer with more stu in it.
HALLER (indifferently) Anne Sturmfuller and her little girl.
Yeah... but what are they doing?
Putting on my Sherlock Holmes deerstalker cap, I deduce that they are leaving.
They are headed out of town all right, but the thing whic perhaps strikes us the most forcibly is how empty this pl is now. Main Street looks like a ghost town.

location: JOE HALLER AND PETE SYLVESTER, ON THE SIDEWALK

text: She's not the only one. Lot of people leaving town. And I guess if we want a beer, we'll have to drink it at home. He nods toward:

location: OWEN'S PUB, LONG, (PETE AND HALLER'S POV)

text: A CLOSED sign hangs in the door; above it is a big black wreath.
Joe, what's wrong with you? I ain't never seen you like this. HALLER (thoughtful) I lost my guts. PETE (startled) Bullshit.

It was the Kincaid boy. I looked at him... and I felt it happen. It was no big deal. No worse than pissing down your own leg. You ever do that? Maybe when you were real scared? PETE, distressed, does not respond.
One minute I had me some guts- as much as the next man, anyhow- and then, poof. Gone. PETE'S looking at him in a kind of terror.
Joe... you are going to feel better than this. This... this feeling of yours... it's gonna pass...
Is it? He walks away, back toward the Municipal Building (the si out front reminds folks to SUPPORT THE MEDCU VAN!) while PETE looks after him, very deeply troubled.
It's deserted. Rides stand still. The midway is deserted. THE CAMERA PANS slowly to a sign which reads TARKER'S MIL FAIRGROUNDS GALA FAIR OCTOBER 1 FIREWORKS AT DUSK 10c ON

head_text.subj: EVERY DOLLAR GOES TO THE MEDCU VAN FUND

text: A cheerful enough sign, except for the strip of paper glu diagonally across it: FIREWORKS CANCELED. MARTY (voice) It's not fair.

head_text.subj: INT. THE COSLAW FAMILY STATION WAGON DAY

text: It's parked across the road from the sign. JANE (voice) Look out, world! Marty the Great didn't get something he wanted! They are distributed just as they were when they arrived this same fairgrounds earlier. All of them have ice cream cones; they are coming home from a family outing.
Stop it, Jane.
Well, I don't see why everybody just about breaks down and cries whenever he-
Stop it, your mother said. They've just paused for a quick look at the sign; now BOB pulls out onto the road again and heads toward home.

location: MARTY AND JANE IN THE BACKSEAT

text: JANE sticks her tongue out at him. MARTY looks away.
UNCLE AL'S sports car is parked in the driveway. We hear CLANG of a wrench on the cement inside.

UNCLE AL and MARTY are working on the engine of the Silve Bullet. UNCLE AL has a six-pack of beer that he's working through. He and MARTY sit on the floor. As they talk, UNC AL unscrews the last bolt holding the Bullet's carburetor and pulls it off.
It isn't enough that the monster killed all those people- that he killed Brady. Now he's got them to cancel the fair.
And the fireworks. Hand me that box, Marty. MARTY hands him a medium-sized carton with the words "Spe Shop" printed on it.
Yeah, okay, the fireworks. Jane thinks that's all I'm mad about, but it's not. Them doing that is just a... a...
It's just an outward symbol of everything that's inwardly wrong in this town. Not bad, huh? I read Sherwood Anderson in college. I can jive that shit all day.
Well... I like it that you always know how to say things, Uncle Al.
I'll give you the telephone numbers of my ex-wives, dear boy- they'll be interested to hear that.
Don't call me dear boy.
But you are, you know- you are my dear boy. He gives MARTY a kiss and smiles at him. MARTY smiles bac

Look at this. He pulls out a brand-new carburetor- it's a chrome-plated four-barrel. UNCLE AL (gleeful) This is gonna turn your wheelchair into a fucking F-14, Marty- He looks around quickly, guiltily.
Your mom's not around, is she?
She and dad are out back lighting the barbecue. Jane's walking around like she's King Shit of Turd Mountain. Like always.
Uh-huh. Only in her case I guess it would be Queen Shit of Turd Mountain. Hand me that adjustable. MARTY does. UNCLE AL slides the carb onto the gasket and starts attaching bolts.
The guy killed your best friend, drove your girl out of town, and stole the second-best holiday in the year. Have I got it right? MARTY (glum) You got it right, Uncle Al.
Yeah, Winesburg, Ohio, was never like that... but I got something that just might cheer you up.
What?
Wait, dear boy. Just wait. Hand me those pliars.

head_text.subj: EXT. UNCLE AL, AT THE SIDE OF THE COSLAW HOUSE DAY

text: He peeks into the backyard.
BOB and NAN are fussing over the barbecue. JANE is hittin badminton birdie.

location: THE ROAD IN FRONT OF COSLAWS', WITH MARTY

text: MARTY is sitting in the Silver Bullet. UNCLE AL comes hurrying back from his look-see.

All is cool, Marty-boy. Go for it. MARTY pushes the starter. The engine starts at once, but tone is entirely different. Before, MARTY'S wheelchair wa poppety-popping pussycat. Now the engine rumbles like a hood's street rod idling at a traffic light. MARTY looks startled. UNCLE AL (grinning) Gun it. MARTY guns it. The engine roars.
Jesus! Not too much! MARTY (awed) Wow.
You got a pilot's license, Marty?
Do I need one?
We're gonna find out. Take it down the road a ways and back. Be careful. MARTY puts the Bullet in gear and pulls away.

CAMERA TRACKS HIM up the road. He goes slowly at first, b he lets it out a little after a while. He's really moving along- thirty, maybe forty miles an hour. The wind blows hair off his forehead. He begins to grin. He's enjoying this.
He drinks some beer. He's grinning, happy for MARTY.
He slows down, turns, stops. He revs the engine. VROOM!
A lot of changes back here. It looks almost like a motorc engine now. That chromed-silver carb predominates.
Grinning. Looking at:
It's about a quarter of a mile away.

He winds the engine up and pops the clutch. The Silver Bullet doesn't so much accelerate as blast off. It tilts back on its wheels. MARTY swivels into a position like th of an astronaut on lift-off. The Silver Bullet looks like motorcycle popping a wheelie. MARTY has a great big grin his face.
Roaring down the highway at fifty or better, blue smoke jetting from the exhaust. MARTY is plastered back in the seat with the footrest pointing up at an angle. He's laughing like a lunatic.

location: UNCLE AL, PEEKING THROUGH HIS FINGERS

text: UNCLE AL (to himself) The kid's dead meat. What have I done? (shouts) Put a rock in it, Marty!
He uses the hand brakes. SOUND of braking and squealing rubber.
The Silver Bullet comes to a screeching, sluing stop near UNCLE AL. Blue smoke drifts up from the wheels. MARTY gun the engine once and then lets it idle.
You gave me a heart attack, Marty. I'm dying. I hope you're happy, because you are looking at a dying man.
It really goes fast. Thanks, Uncle Al.
It goes fast, all right- and if your mother finds out just how fast, Marty, I will have a new job. Singing soprano with the Vienna Boys' Choir.
I don't get you.
I know you don't. But I want this to be our secret. You get that, don't you?
Sure.
Good.

location: THE NIGHT SKY, WITH THE MOON

text: The last bit of daylight is just filtering away.
The barbecue is over. BOB and JANE are putting lawn chair on the back porch. MARTY, NAN, and UNCLE AL are all in th f.g.
I've got to go, Nan- I had a wonderful time. He kisses her cheek affectionately, and she smiles at him
So have I, actually... I wish it could always be like this.
See me around to my car, Marty, and make sure I stay out of trouble at least that long.
Okay. He and UNCLE AL go around to the driveway. NAN looks at t with troubled love.

location: THE COSLAW DRIVEWAY, WITH MARTY AND UNCLE AL

text: Now I said I had something for you, as I believe you will recall.

Yeah! What is it? AL unlocks the trunk of his car and brings out a paper shopping bag. He places the bag in MARTY'S lap. MARTY ope the bag, but it's really too dark to see inside. He reach in and brings out a handful of assorted fireworks- cracke Roman candles, twizzers, smoke bombs, etc. An expression of sublime delight fills MARTY'S face as he inventories these goodies.

You're gonna have the Fourth of July in October, Marty. Just don't blow your head off. (Pause) And remember that it isn't just the fireworks. It's because no crazy shithead should be able to stop the good guys, if you can dig that. MARTY (respectfully) I can dig it- thank you, Uncle Al! Thank you!
Stay near the house, for Christ's sake- someone's killing people. I have to be out of my mind to be doing this, you know.
Yeah, I know. It's great!
One of the reasons I love you, Marty, is that you're almost as crazy as I am. Please don't set off anything that goes bang tonight, okay? Just bright colors. Can you tell the difference?
Yeah... sure.
