Save this one for last. He brings out a short rocket with stubby vanes on the end fat fuse sticks out behind the head.
What is it?
A tracer. You'll like it.
Thanks a million, Uncle Al!

You're welcome a million, Marty. Stick 'em in the bushes for now. MARTY motors over to the side of the garage, where there' line of bushes, and conceals the bag in them. UNCLE AL ge in his car and starts it up. MARTY comes back. UNCLE AL (grinning) Have a good time, dear boy! And watch out for the werewolves! He leaves. MARTY sits in his wheelchair, waving.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE REAR OF THE COSLAW HOUSE NIGHT

text: There's a downspout outside one of the upstairs windows. the window goes up and MARTY leans out. He grasps the downspout and begins working his way down. This should no be too hard for us to believe; we've already seen how str MARTY'S arms are. His legs dangle limply, but he's doing just fine. When he reaches the bottom of the drainpipe, they simply crumple under him and he uses his arms to pull himself over to th back porch. MARTY hoists himself over the porch rail. Here, under a tarp, is the Silver Bullet. MARTY pushes the tarp aside a gets in. He uses his hands on the wheels to get over the porch ramp and rolls silently down it. At the bottom he looks up at:
Still a light on up there.
MARTY (whispers) Shit! Thinks a bit, then starts to hand-roll the Bullet toward:

location: THE PATH BETWEEN THE HOUSE AND THE GARAGE

text: MARTY comes slowly up the path. We hear soft grunts of exertion; he's still hand-turning the wheels for the sake silence, and it's hard work. He stops at the line of bush and gets the bag of fireworks. He puts it on his lap and starts moving again.

location: THE COSLAW DRIVEWAY, FROM THE ROAD

text: The driveway has a slight downslant, and MARTY coasts eas out to the road. He turns right and begins to roll slowly along the verge of the highway, still using his hands. We can see that the light is still on upstairs. MARTY turns back once to verify this himself, then keeps on going. He not going to be deprived of his treat.

He decides he's far enough away to be safe. He pushes the starter button. The engine cranks, coughs, and cranks som more. MARTY frowns, and pulls out a wire- a rudimentary choke, I suppose. He pushes the starter button again. It cranks, but doesn't start. MARTY pushes in the wire, looking concerned now, and trie again. This time, after the engine has cranked over a few times, it starts. MARTY (softly) All right! He puts it in gear and starts off.

location: THE ROAD, WITH MARTY, EXTREMELY LONG

text: What we see is a tiny boy in a tiny wheelchair moving alo a dark, empty ribbon of road under a vast dome of stars. DISTANT SOUND: The Bullet's engine.

SOUND: Fast-rushing water. The turnout is packed dirt. There's a grove of trees with picnic tables spotted among them at the back. The sign in the extreme f.g. reads ROADSIDE REST AREA at the top; AUG FALLS in the middle; TOWNSHIP OF TARKER'S MILLS at the bottom. SOUND: The Silver Bullet approaching. MARTY turns in and rolls to the back of the rest area. He stops by one of the picnic tables and dumps the bag of fireworks out onto the picnic table and takes his time selecting the first- he's like a wine fancier with a whol cellar of rare bottles to choose from. At last he chooses twizzer. He takes matches from the pocket of his pajama t and lights the fuse. When it starts to fizz, MARTY tosses it high into the air MARTY (soft) Here's one for the good guys!
It flies in an arc over the drop.

location: THE TWIZZER, FROM THE BOTTOM OF THE CUT

text: THE CAMERA TRACKS ITS FALL onto some rocks at the edge of the waterfall's catch pool. SOUND: Growling.
It has been drinking from the creek. It looks more than h human now- we would be able to recognize it for sure, but its face is in shadow. It turns from the creek and gets up on its hind legs.
It's guttering out. A hand-paw touches it and draws back quickly. SOUND: Hurt, angry growl.

He's getting ready to light one of the fountains. He paus and looks toward the cut. He's heard something- but the waterfall muffles it. He lights the fountain's fuse, sets on the ground, and rolls the Bullet back a few feet. The fountain bursts into a shower of light. MARTY (delighted) All right!

location: THE SLOPE OF THE CUT, MEDIUM LONG

text: The waterfall is in the b.g. The WEREWOLF is climbing the rocky slope.
It goes out.
He rolls over to the picnic table and gets a Roman candle He plants the stick in the ground and lights the fuse. Th Roman candle shoots into the sky.
Bursts into colored light.

location: THE WEREWOLF, NEAR THE TOP OF THE CUT, MEDIUM LONG

text: It GROWLS... and shakes its fists at the fading light in sky.
He's holding another fountain in one hand and his matches the other. He's looking toward the cut and the waterfall.
Is someone there?

location: THE WEREWOLF, NEAR THE TOP OF THE CUT

text: It freezes, GROWLING FAINTLY.
With a little shrug, he lights the fuse on the fountain a sets it on the ground, as before.

location: THE BACK OF THE GROVE, AT THE TOP OF THE CUT

text: Claw-hands settle over the top.
It throws off fiery swirls of sparks, then begins to die down.
He's checking out the stuff on the table for his next cho when he hears a clear SOUND: A SNAPPING, SPLINTERING BRAN

It's run into a low-hanging branch. Instead of pushing it aside or ducking under it, it simply rips it off the tree Although the branch is pretty big, the WEREWOLF does this easily as a hungry man might rip a drumstick off a Thanksgiving turkey. It throws the branch aside and advances, hunched over on two legs.
MARTY (terrified) Who's there?
The grove is a darkened shadowland.

He punches the Bullet's starter. The motor cranks and cranks. No go, though. MARTY pulls out the choke wire, alternating terrified stares at the grove of trees with terrified stares at his rudimentary dashboard.
Here it comes, out of the shadows, closing in.
Working that starter for all it's worth... but the motor only cranks. Still no start.

He gives up on the motor. He looks toward the picnic tabl where the fireworks are. He grabs up the tracer. He gets matches out of the breast pocket of his p.j.'s and prompt drops them in his lap. He scrabbles for them.
We can't see its face in the dark, but it's closer... muc closer.
He tries to hold the tracer and strike a match at the sam time. He can't; to do that he'd need at least one more hand. He puts the tube of the tracer between his teeth and tries again.
He strikes the match... too hard! It bends, the neck brok MARTY (voice; moaning) Oh, please...
He is in an extremity of terror.

location: THE MATCHBOOK AND MARTY'S HANDS, CU

text: He pulls a fresh match from the book and strikes it. It lights.

It recoils- we still can't see its face except for a vagu shadow. (NOTE: I keep emphasizing the shadowed face, because this not a full-moon period. I've been going on the assumption that the guy kind of works his way up to full wolfiness, toothiness, hairiness, etc., starting with a partial chan at about the second quarter. It's a process like the tide coming in. Thus, if we saw MARTY'S attacker clearly at th point, I think we would recognize him.)
He takes the tracer from his mouth and applies the match the fuse. It splutters alight.
The WEREWOLF is less than twenty feet away. The tracer flares alight and shoots out of MARTY'S hand, leaving a pink-orange trail of smoke behind it. The missile flies a the WEREWOLF's head.
The tracer strikes it in the face, and we see a flash of fire. The WEREWOLF screams and blunders away.
He punches the starter again. The motor cranks.

location: THE MOTOR OF THE SILVER BULLET

text: The motor coughs and fires; a big blue flame jumps from t fancy carb... and the engine starts to run.
It's staggering away, ROARING and HOWLING. The tube of th tracer is sticking out of its face- from its left eye, in fact- like an Indian's arrow. The WEREWOLF smashes branch out of its way.
He wheels the Bullet around and heads for the road, gaspi and weeping with fear.
It's blundering through the trees. It pulls the tube from its face with an ANIMAL SCREAM and drops it.
It lies smoldering on the ground. The end is slick with blood.
The Bullet is really wheeling. MARTY is panting, out of breath, still deeply frightened.
We see it blundering along, holding its face; blood bubbl through its fingers. WEREWOLF (snarling voice) Bastard Marty! Bastard Marty! Kill you! Reeeal slow!
He powers up it, and along the path to the back. Perhaps has enough speed to cut the engine and coast.
His bed is by the window. His hands appear on the windowsill, and MARTY pulls himself in. He falls over ont his bed and lies there, spent and exhausted and trembling

head_text.subj: EXT. THE COSLAW HOUSE, VERY EARLY MORNING

location: THE COSLAW LIVING ROOM, WITH MARTY

text: He's sitting in the "house" wheelchair in the living room holding the phone tensely to his ear as the RINGING SOUND goes on. A CLICK as the phone is picked up. UNCLE AL (muzzy voice) 'Lo? Go away.
It's a werewolf! I saw it! Last night-

Not a really spiffy place- the decor is Early American Alcoholic. There's a mostly unclad lady asleep on one sid of the bed. UNCLE AL is sitting on the other in his skivvies, phone to his ear. There are a lot of bottles an heaped ashtrays around, and UNCLE AL has a big old hangov
You dreamed it, Marty. MARTY (voice) No! I went out late last night- and-
There are no such things as werewolves. Please, dear boy, have some pity. He hangs up and falls back into bed. GIRL (muzzy voice) Whowuzzit?
Obscene phone caller. Go back to sleep.
He's sitting on the Silver Bullet, just looking at the ya JANE comes out.
Marty? You okay? You've just been sitting here all morning.
Where's Mom?
Went shopping. Why?
Jane, I have to talk to you. JANE (mistrustfully) About what? MARTY looks at her earnestly.
I need you to help me. Uncle Al won't believe me, and if you won't help me, I... I... MARTY has to stop. He's almost crying. JANE (concerned) Marty, what is it?

location: MAIN STREET, MEDIUM LONG, WITH JANE

text: JANE is pushing a supermarket shopping cart with a lot of beer and soda bottles in it. On the side is a sign readin MEDCU BOTTLE AND CAN DRIVE- plus an outline drawing of th Medcu unit. JANE (voice-over) He told me something that was clearly unbelievable... and yet, somehow I believed most of it. And I understood one thing with total clarity: Marty himself believed it all. She turns into a yard and pulls her cart up the walk to t door. She mounts the steps and rings the bell.

A sheer curtain at one side of the door is pulled aside a a fearful face- that of MRS. THAYER- looks out. Then we h bolts being pulled and locks- at least three of them- bei unlocked. The lady is taking no chances.
Jane? JANE (politely) I'm collecting returnable bottles and cans for the Medcu Drive, Missus Thayer- I just wondered if you had any. Her husband comes up the hall.
Who is it?
Jane Coslaw.
What we see mostly are her eyes- bright, inquiring.
Hi, Mr. Thayer.
What we see mostly are his brown eyes.
Hello, Jane.

location: THE PORCH, WITH JANE AND MRS. THAYER

text: Bring your cart around to the back, Jane- we'll look in the garage.
Thank you. She starts down the steps and we

head_text.subj: EXT. JANE, ON MAIN STREET DAY

text: Amazing how deserted Tarker's Mills looks. JANE is pushin her cart. Even more bottles in it now. JANE (voice-over) Uncle Al hadn't believed him, but Uncle Al was thirty-five that summer and I was fourteen... at fourteen you can still believe the unbelievable, although even then that ability is growing rusty, is preparing to squeal to a stop. She is passing the Holy Family rectory. LESTER LOWE is ou front, digging in his flower garden. He is shirtless, bac to JANE and to us; his black shirt with the turned-around collar hangs informally on a bush. JANE (calls) Hi, Father Lowe! LOWE (without turning) Top of the morning to you, Jane Coslaw!
I'm going to bring in a monster load of bottles in an hour or so! LOWE (still digging) That's great, Jane... I'll be waiting.

She stops at Robertson's Luncheonette, leaves her cart outside, and goes in. THE CAMERA FLOATS TO THE WINDOW; we see JANE explaining about the bottle campaign to BOBBY wh a few men seated at the counter listen.
Wide eyes, mostly.
Mostly eyes.
As she turns away, her eyes sweep the men at the counter.
Some of them- PELTZER, VIRGIL CUTTS- are familiar. Others are not. THE CAMERA PANS THEIR FACES CLOSELY, FEATURING THEIR EYES.

She grabs the handle of the cart again and proceeds down Main Street. She goes into the barber shop. JANE (v-o) Marty had seen where the tracer had struck home, he said, and I went out that day doing more than just looking for returnable cans and bottles- I was looking for a man- or woman- with only one eye.

As JANE enters, BILLY McCLAREN is giving one man a trim. Another man is tipped back with his face wrapped in a tow Two or three other townies are waiting on tonsorial beautification, reading magazines. None, of course, has o one eye. JANE checks them all out carefully.
I know what you're after, Jane, and you're out of luck. Little Toby Whittislaw was in yesterday, and I gave 'em all to him.
Oh... okay. But her eyes have fixed on the towel over the face of the man in the other barber chair. She walks over to him.

That you, Mr. Fairton? ANDY FAIRTON (muffled) No- it's Ronald McDonald. I came in for a shave and a burger. The men laugh. JANE smiles politely. And pulls the hot to away from his eyes. His two eyes. JANE (sweetly) Got any bottles, Mr. Fairton?
No! JANE (just as sweet) Oh... okay. She puts the towel back and THE CAMERA FOLLOWS as she returns to the door.
'Bye, Mr. McClaren. BILLY (amused) 'Bye, Jane. ANDY (muffled) Jesus! JANE goes out.
She pushes the shopping cart up to the gate, opens it, an goes up the walk to the foot of LOWE'S porch steps. She leaves it there and climbs to the porch.
The screen door is shut, the inner wooden door open.
Dark and empty. SOUNDS in the kitchen. EATING SOUNDS, may or maybe we can't tell.
She knocks on the screen door.
Father Lowe! I'm ready to turn in my bottles and cans!

LOWE is standing by the refrigerator door. He's holding a raw leg of lamb and tearing at it with his teeth. Lamb bl smears his face and runs down his arms. He is as human as you or me (in a manner of speaking, as UNCLE AL would say but when JANE speaks, his head snaps up and his eye flare his one eye. The other is covered by a patch. JANE (voice) Father?
Take your cart around to the garage and unload, Jane! Then bring me your tally sheet!
Okay!
She goes down the steps and starts to push the cart aroun the house.
He crosses to the window over the kitchen sink, the blood chunk of meat still in his hands, and looks out.
She pushes the cart along a path toward a combination gar and utility shed at the back.
Still watching JANE, he begins to gnaw ravenously at the meat again.
She opens the door and slowly pushes her cart inside.

This is a creepy little place, now filled with bottles an cans that have been crammed in helter-skelter, every whic way. JANE obviously doesn't like it. She begins to unload her cart rapidly, mumbling numbers to herself. SOUND: SQUEAKING. JANE looks down.
A good-sized mouse comes out from between a pile of stack bottles and runs across JANE'S shoe.

She utters a litle scream and shrinks back against the wa bumping it quite hard. Hard enough to knock something off overhead shelf. It falls into the bottles, SHATTERING several. JANE screams again- not terribly loud- and then slowly bends toward the object and picks it up. JANE holds it, both puzzled and scared.

location: THE BACK DOOR OF THE RECTORY

text: JANE approaches it, holding a piece of paper in her hand- her tally sheet. She knocks. Waits. There is no answer. S knocks again. Waits. No answer. She tries the door. It opens.
Father Lowe? No answer. After a moment of interior debate, JANE enters the kitchen.
She looks around. No one here. But there is a bloody spot the counter- LOWE must have set his grisly luncheon down here for a moment. She walks slowly across the kitchen an into the dark hall.
Father Lowe?... I've got my tally sheet... Farther into the hall. A hand drops onto her shoulder. LOWE (voice) Very good, Jane! She jumps, and so do we. She turns around and looks up at

Featuring his eyes- his eye, rather. The left is covered with a black eye-patch. LOWE (grins) Good, Jane. Very... very good. He holds his hand out, and JANE puts the tally sheet in i like one in a dream. She can't take her eyes off that bla patch, which tells her everything.

location: THE HALLWAY, WITH JANE AND LOWE

text: LOWE (concerned) Jane! You're trembling!
I... I don't feel so well, I guess maybe I got too much sun.
Would you like to come in the parlor and lie down for a bit? Or have a cold drink? I have some soda-
No! (softer) That is, I have to get home and help my mom with lunch.
I'll give you a ride! JANE is retreating down the hall toward the front door.
No- she... she was going to meet me at the market. I'll be fine.
How much does he know? How much has he guessed? Hard to t from his face, which now seems sinister, with its eye-pat
Give my best to your brother, Jane.

location: JANE, AT THE PORCH END OF THE HALLWAY

text: I will. She bolts.
CAMERA HOLDS ON HIM, standing silent and enigmatic. LOWE (soft) Real slow.
His eyes are wide. He's leaning forward in his wheelchair MARTY (almost moaning) Oh, Jeez! What did you do then?
She's changed into shorts and a blouse.

I ran faster than I ever ran in my life- what do you think, dummox? By the time I got back here, I really thought I was going to faint. (Pause) What are we going to do, Marty? If we tried to tell anybody- grown-ups, I mean- they'd laugh. What are we going to do? MARTY (thoughtfully) I think I know.

location: A SHEET OF RULED SCHOOL NOTEBOOK PAPER, CU

text: A hand- MARTY'S- comes into the frame and prints: I KNOW YOU ARE, AND I KNOW WHAT YOU ARE.
He's sitting at his desk, a pool of light from the lamp focused on the sheet of paper before him. He thinks a moment, then begins to write again.
He is adding: WHY DON'T YOU KILL YOURSELF?
He studies this for a second, and seems satisfied. He ope a drawer, brings out an envelope, and folds his letter in it.
She has the letter in her hand. She approaches the mailbo opens the mailbox door, and then glances at the envelope again.
Addressed in pencil, it says: FATHER LESTER LOWE/HOLY FAM RECTORY; 149 MAIN STREET/TARKER'S MILLS, MAINE.
She drops the letter in with the air of a girl lighting t fuse on a packet of high explosives. She turns away towar home.

location: THE RECTORY LIVING ROOM, WITH LESTER LOWE

text: He's standing at the window and looking out. The torn-ope envelope is on an end table beside him. He's holding the lined sheet of paper in his hand. An expression of bitter hate twists his features, and he slowly crumples the pape in his fist.

location: JANE, AT THE MAIN STREET MAILBOX

text: She drops in another letter and walks away. JANE (v-o) I mailed another letter for Marty the next day... a third the day after that. Then, on Saturday...
Parked at the curb is UNCLE AL'S sports car. JANE (v-o) ...we told Uncle Al what we'd been up to. (Pause) His reaction was less than serene.

location: UNCLE AL, JANE, AND MARTY, ON THE COMMON

text: Holy-jumped-up-baldheaded-Jesus-CHRIST!

Uncle Al- UNCLE AL (to JANE) From him I'd expect it. I sometimes think his common sense got paralyzed along with his legs. But you, Jane! You! Little Polly Practical! JANE (quiet) You don't understand. UNCLE AL (wildly) Oh, I understand plenty! I understand that my niece and nephew are sending the local Catholic priest little love notes suggesting that he gargle with a broken light bulb or eat a rat-poison omelet!
It came for me! I shot it in the eye! Now he's wearing an eye-patch!
I called Peltzer on my way over here, Marty! Father Lowe came into the drugstore two days ago for a bottle of otic solution. That's a fancy way of saying eyewash. He's got a corneal inflammation.
Was it a prescription?
What the hell does that matter?
It wasn't- I'll bet you it wasn't. Because to get a prescription he'd have to see a doctor.
Marty, Marty, you should hear yourself!
Well... was it a prescription?
I don't know. But I know you didn't see any werewolf the other night, Marty. You had a dream, that's all. An extremely realistic nightmare brought on by what's been happening in this town.

What about the baseball bat Jane saw in his shed? You know who used to have a baseball bat like that? Mr. Knopfler! He was so proud of it he used to carry it in the Fourth of July parade! Jane said it looked like the Green Giant used it for a toothpick!
You want to know what I think?
No- we just got you out here so we could admire your pretty face.
Watch it, dear boy. I think it was a hallucination. Probably a broomstick, or something. JANE (indignant) It was not! You want me to show you! Come on! I'm not afraid! I'll show you right now!
No thank you, Jane. I'm a little old for palying the Hardy Boys Meet the Catholic Werewolf. JANE stamps her foot, furious with UNCLE AL.
Never mind, Jane. He'll have gotten rid of it by now anyway.

The Silver Bullet stands outside. The door opens and UNCL AL, JANE, and MARTY come out. UNCLE AL is carrying MARTY piggyback. MARTY has an ice cream cone. JANE is holding t UNCLE AL squats, depositing MARTY in the Bullet. MARTY starts the engine as JANE hands UNCLE AL his ice cream co The three of them start up the street and THE CAMERA TRAC THEM.
If Father Lowe is an innocent little lamb, why hasn't he picked up the telephone and called Constable Haller to tell him Marty's sending poison-pen letters?
I don't accept the idea that he knows who his letter writer is, Jane. Because I don't accept the idea that there was a big bad wolf who saw Marty in his wheelchair.
Why hasn't he picked up the phone and told Constable Haller that someone is sending him poison-pen letters? UNCLE AL stops. He hasn't thought of this. He looks towar
LESTER LOWE is mowing the lawn, eye-patch and all.

location: MAIN STREET, WITH UNCLE AL, MARTY, AND JANE

text: UNCLE AL (a bit perplexed) Well... he probably did. I mean, he could make a complaint without taking an ad out in the paper, couldn't he?
I'll bet you a quarter that eyewash stuff was nonprescription. And I'll bet you another quarter he hasn't said anything to Mr. Haller.
Marty, do you see your suspect?

location: THE RECTORY LAWN, WITH LESTER LOWE

text: Keeps on moving. MR. ASPINALL drives by and waves. LOWE waves back.

location: MAIN STREET, WITH UNCLE AL, MARTY, AND JANE

text: MARTY (grim) Yes, I see him.
Do you really think that a man who took a rocket in the eye three nights ago could be out mowing his lawn? He'd either be in the hospital... or dead.
I didn't shoot him when he was a man. I shot him when he was-
When he was a werewolf. Yes. Right. Jesus. Jane, you don't really believe this madness, do you?

I don't know exactly what I believe. But I know that what I saw was a baseball bat and not a broomstick. I know there was something strange about the way the house smelled that day. It smelled like an animal's den. And I believe in Marty. I mean- there are times when he makes me so mad I could kill him, but I still believe in him. (Pause) You used to believe in him, too, Uncle Al. UNCLE AL looks momentarily ashamed of himself. Then he throws his hands up in disgust.
Kids! He walks ahead of them. MARTY bats his eyes sweetly at JA She walks on, miffed. MARTY gooses the Silver Bullet to catch up.

head_text.subj: EXT. A FIELD ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF TOWN DAY

text: It's midafternoon. A bunch of kids are playing baseball. the extreme f.g. we see one small boy- MARTY- sitting bac to us in his wheelchair, watching.
It draws slowly along a tree-lined lane and stops. LESTER LOWE is behind the wheel. SOUNDS OF THE BASEBALL GAME CONTINUE.

head_text.subj: THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN ON MARTY'S BACK.

text: LOWE (quietly) Little bastard.
The field team heads in. Kids start streaming back toward town.
The OUTFIELDER who caught the fly trots past, and glances his way.
You comin' down to Robertson's for a soda, Marty?
No- I guess I'll go home. I think that here we are seeing a rare moment of depressi in MARTY- they can run and play ball. He can't.
Okay- seeya!
Yeah... seeya. He fires up the Bullet and starts away alone.
He starts it up.
He bumps up a grassy slope to a tarred road. The last of other kids are headed back the other way. MARTY is alone.
It turns out of the lane where it was parked and onto the road.
MARTY'S back is to us. The wheelchair draws rapidly close to THE CAMERA as LOWE bears down on it.
He leans over the wheel, grinning sadistically. LOWE (whispers) Bastard.
He's daydreaming his way along- maybe, inside his head, h playing center field for the Dodgers. SOUND: Winding roar of a car engine. MARTY turns around.

MARTY opens the throttle wide and the Bullet swerves acro the road. The coupe's bumper actually clips it on the way by, jolting MARTY and almost overturning the Bullet. LOWE'S coupe veers over the embankment and partway down i the ditch.

location: LOWE, BEHIND THE WHEEL OF THE COUPE

text: Oh, you bastard! He floors the engine.
Spinning helplessly in the dirt.
He speeds past the coupe, and thumbs his nose.
He's in a teeth-grinding fury. He jams the gear-shift lev into reverse and floors the gas pedal again.
It roars backward in a cloud of ditch dust and bounces on the road. Then it screams out after the rapidly disappear Silver Bullet.
He hears the GROWLING SOUND of LESTER LOWE'S coupe. He lo behind.
Roars toward THE CAMERA.
He twists the throttle and the Silver Bullet responds.

The director will shoot it as he likes- the basis is simp LOWE is chasing MARTY's hopped-up wheelchair along a coun road at speeds approaching fifty MPH. MARTY should have a couple of near misses, and perhaps we could actually have him pass one car. At one point we should have a REVERSE ANGLE on LESTER LOWE'S coupe, featuring two bumper sticke ATTEND AND SUPPORT YOUR LOCAL CHURCH and HONK IF YOU LOVE
As the chase goes on it becomes apparent that LOWE is gaining. MARTY looks increasingly desperate. And now he looks down at:
The needle is all the way over on "E."
He groans. SOUND of the coupe's engine GROWS LOUDER.

location: THE COUPE AND THE SILVER BULLET

text: LOWE charges, rapidly closing the distance. MARTY swerves from one side of the road to the other, escaping LOWE for the moment but almost overturning in the process. They are now running beside a river- the Auger River, in fact.
Now the needle is actually past "E."
Come on, baby... come on... His face registers hope as he sees:

head_text.subj: AUGER RIVER COVERED BRIDGE 2000 FEET AHEAD AUTOMOBILES

text: He twists the throttle as far as it will turn- he's going for broke. The coupe chases him- and now the Silver Bulle motor COUGHS.
It's pretty ramshackle. A big orange sign beside it reads

MARTY brakes, hits the shoulder of the road, and somehow makes the turn. We see him holding on for dear life as th Silver Bullet bounces and jounces down the dirt road to t mouth of the covered bridge.
It overshoots the right turn MARTY just took, screeches t halt, backs up, and turns onto the lane.
It bounces up the incline to the bridge, MOTOR COUGHING A SPLUTTERING.
It comes to a sliding, dirt-digging stop.
His face is so full of frustrated hate that it has become the face of a gargoyle.

location: THE COVERED BRIDGE, WITH THE BULLET

text: It's dim and spooky in here. Cracks between the boards of the side walls allow dusty fingers of daylight to shine through. More light rays up from the cracks in the floor. The floorboards are warped and uneven; MARTY'S wheelchair sways drunkenly from side to side. The total inside passa is about seventy feet. About halfway across, the Silver Bullet coughs its last cough and splutters its last splutter. It rolls along silently, going on its dying momentum.
Drawing closer. We hear the SOUNDS of boards rumbling und the Silver Bullet's tires and the Auger River beneath.
Rolling ever more slowly, the Silver Bullet approaches TH CAMERA... and stops. MARTY is covered with sweat. His hai is in a wild tangle. He's panting. He looks at:
This is an extremely rustic lane. Pretty, but hardly the sort of place in which one would want to find oneself whe one has a part-time werewolf and a full-time homicidal maniac close behind.

location: MARTY, AT THE MOUTH OF THE BRIDGE

text: LOWE (soft voice) Marty... MARTY'S head whips around.
We see a brilliant square of light. In it stands LOWE'S silhouette. The silhouette begins to move. SOUND of footfalls on the loose floorboards of the covered bridge.
Sensible black Oxfords.
I'm very sorry about this. I don't know if you believe that or not, but it's true. I would never willingly hurt a child. You should have left me alone, Marty. SOUND of footfalls resumes.
He's nearly paralyzed with terror- even if he wasn't, he wouldn't get far in a powerless Silver Bullet.

LOWE (soft; soothing) I can't kill myself, Marty. You see, our religion teaches that suicide is the greatest sin a man or a woman can commit. Stella Randolph was going to commit suicide; if she had done so, she would be burning in hell right now. By killing her I took her physical life but saved her life eternal. You see, Marty? You see how all things serve the will and the mind of God? You see, you meddling little shit! He begins to walk forward again.
He's halfway across the bridge now, walking slowly, not hurrying.
You're going to have a terrible accident, Marty. You're going to fall into the river. SOUND: TRACTOR ENGINE. LOWE stops, alert to possible dang
MARTY'S face fills with hope. He looks from LOWE toward:
THE TRACTOR SOUND gets louder still, and here comes ELMER ZINNEMAN on a John Deere. The tractor is hauling a manure spreader which is mostly empty.
MARTY (waving madly) Mr. Zinneman! Mr. Zinneman!
He draws back a little, and his face is sharp with animal cunning- inside his head he's running a four-minute mile. Stay and try to bluff it out, or beat it?
ELMER draws the tractor up close to MARTY and swings it around. MARTY looks back at:
Empty. SOUND OF A CAR STARTING, FAINT.
MARTY looks back at ELMER.
I ran out of gas.
Spooky in there, ennit? MARTY (with feeling) It sure is! He looks back once more toward:
Brooding, shadowy. CAMERA HOLDS AND WE
MARTY is talking to UNCLE AL. JANE is behind them, knocki croquet balls through the wickets on the back lawn. MARTY is looking at his Uncle anxiously as JANE strolls over.
Well... it's a lot easier to swallow without the hair and the foaming jaws. Also, I checked on the otic solution. It was counter brand. No prescription needed.
I told you!
Shut up, dear boy- no gloating allowed. JANE (sits down) Did you talk to the constable?
After Marty called me with his latest Thrilling Tale of Wonder, I did. (Pause) He's had no poison-pen complaints lodged at all.
I told you!
Shut up, Marty. UNCLE AL (reluctantly) There's something else.
What is it?                                        What o
I probably shouldn't tell you- you're both hysterical on the subject. I'm starting to feel like a guy handing out free Arthur Murray coupons to victims of the dancing sickness.
Uncle Al, if you don't tell me- He makes strangling gestures. UNCLE AL (reluctant) I went out to that rest area. MARTY (triumph) You found the tracer?
No... but I found some blood, smeared on a tree trunk in that grove.
There! You see!
It could have been anything, Marty.
What about Father Lowe chasing me in his car and trying to run me down? You don't think that was a dream, do you?
No. UNCLE AL comes over to JANE'S side of the Silver Bullet. looks down at:
There's a scrape and a dent where LOWE'S coupe dented it. There is also a fleck of paint.
Lowe's car-?
Blue. This blue.
Jesus.

location: THE NIGHT SKY, WITH THE MOON

text: Three-quarters full. THE CAMERA PANS DOWN to the Tarker's Mills town hall. UNC AL'S sports car is parked out front.

location: THE CONSTABLE'S OFFICE, WITH HALLER AND UNCLE AL

text: HALLER is behind his desk, rocked back in his chair, hand laced together behind his head. He's looking at UNCLE AL. There's a silence that draws out for quite some time. In UNCLE AL becomes steadily more uncomfortable.
That's just about the craziest damn story I've ever heard, Al.
I know. I could have edited out all of the completely crazy stuff, but I thought you deserved to hear it with the bark on.
I appreciate that. Now, the next question: Do you believe any of this? You do, don't you?
Let's just say I believe Lester Lowe should be checked out. HALLER rises.
That can be arranged. They shake hands.

A Chevrolet with TARKER'S MILLS CONSTABLE painted on the side in gold leaf pulls up. JOE HALLER gets out, and as h does there's a business of pulling his pants legs down ov his boots- nice stitched cowboy boots, not black cop's shoes. We want the audience to notice these boots, rememb them- probably HALLER should wear them all through the picture. He goes up the walk. HALLER rings the doorbell. No one comes. HALLER rings the bell again. Waits. No one comes. He leans down and looks through a side window.
No one there.
He goes down the steps, stands on the path for a moment, then goes over to the shed-garage. He opens the door and looks in.
LOWE'S coupe is in there. There's just room for it amid t shadowy piles of bottles and cans.

He goes around to the front of LOWE'S coupe and squats do In the b.g.: a heaped mountain of aluminum beer and soda cans. HALLER feels in his breast pocket and brings out a Zippo. lights it and looks at:

One of the turn-signal lamps is broken. There's a scratch the paint and a dent in the bumper. HALLER'S fingers come into the frame and touch the scratch. They stop, and THE CAMERA ZOOMS IN to a small streak of silvery paint. As MA has a scrape of blue car paint on his wheelchair, so does LOWE have a scrape of silver wheelchair paint on his car.

His eyes widen. SOUND: SHATTERING ROAR and the CLINK AND TUMBLE of about nine thousand cans as LOWE erupts from under the aluminum scrap heap behind HALLER. He is a mixture of man and werewolf, and quite clearly a beastial version of LOWE. I one hand he holds the remains of OWEN KNOPFLER'S peacemak HALLER starts to turn; LOWE strikes him with the bat. CAM CLOSES IN ON LOWE as the bat rises and falls... rises and falls. We can't see HALLER, and that is probably a mercy, but we can hear the THUD of the bat as it strikes again a again and again.

location: THE REST AREA AT AUGER FALLS, WITH MARTY, AL, JANE

text: UNCLE AL has taken the Coslaw family station wagon today. The three of them are sitting in the grove of trees.
Mr. Haller said he'd check him out, and guess what? No one sees him again!
And what do you suggest I do about it, dear boy? MARTY slips off his St. Christopher's medallion and hands to UNCLE AL.
I want you to turn this into a silver bullet.
You're not going to let it go, are you?
I saw what I saw.

Marty, the moon wasn't even full! JANE (quietly) In the made-up stories, the guy who's the werewolf only changes when the moon is full. But maybe he's really that way almost all the time, only as the moon gets fuller... MARTY (finishes) ...the guy gets wolfier. JANE (hands AL her crucifix) Here. Take mine, too.
Jane... you don't have to do that.
Don't tell me what I have to do and what I don't, booger-brains.
Will you marry me, Jane?
Would you kids mind telling me how this guy Lowe became a werewolf to begin with?
I don't know. Maybe he doesn't know, either.
No one knows how cancer begins, either- or exactly what it is- but people still believe in it.
The kid is eleven years old and already he sounds like a Jesuit. A French Jesuit.
I think he's going to come for me. Not just because I know who he is, but because I hurt him. Only I don't think he'll try again as Lowe.
Dear boy, you have gone right out of your mind.
Will you do it? UNCLE AL only looks at him, confused and unsure.

head_text.subj: EXT. A COUNTRY ROAD, WITH THE COSLAW STATION WAGON DAY

text: UNCLE AL is taking the kids home- THE CAMERA TRACKS the wagon for a moment, and then we are looking up the short lane and into a gravel pit. THE CAMERA ZOOMS IN, FAST, on the sandy rear wall. We can see one cowboy boot sticking out of a wall of sand. It's bloody and chewed.
The wagon pulls in.

location: THE CAR, WITH MARTY, JANE, AND UNCLE AL

text: Please, Uncle Al.
Will you? The St. Cristopher's medal and the crucifix are hanging f the rearview on a fine silver chain. UNCLE AL takes down medal and looks at it.
All right. I give up. Yes.
All right! Thanks!                                Thank y
If either of you ever tells anyone I even bought a piece of this story, werewolves will be the least of your problems.

a.) UNCLE AL pulls up to a city store front with a sign reading MAC'S GUNS AND AMMO. He takes out the St. Cristopher's medal, looks at it, and shakes his head, as still ruing his own credulity and stupidity. He goes insi JANE (voice-over) Uncle Al's friend Mac was more than a gunsmith; he was, Uncle Al said, an old-world craftsman, a sort of wizard of weapons. b.) In the gun shop interior, we see UNCLE AL talking to MAC, who really should look like an elderly white wizard- kind of Gandalf figure. In the b.g. window we see a paper skeleton and paper jack-o'-lanterns: our first clue that Hallow's Eve is nearing. UNCLE AL is speaking animatedly, using his hands a lot; we don't know exactly what the tal is, but it must be a whopper. In the course of it, he han the medal and the crucifix to MAC, who tents the silver chains over his fingers and looks at them. JANE (v-o continues) God knows what sort of story my uncle told him, but I think that for men who have been married as often as Uncle Al, invention on short notice becomes something of a specialty. c.) In his workroom, we see MAC spilling boron over the medal and looking closely at the stain. JANE (v-o continues) The gunsmith confirmed the high-grade silver content of my crucifix and Marty's medallion... d.) In a dim shot which makes MAC look more like a sorcer than ever, we see him light an acetylene torch and begin melting the medal and the crucifix in the crucible. THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN as JANE'S contribution and MARTY'S melt together; they are becoming on and indissoluble. JANE (v-o continues) ...melted them down... e.) We see MAC pouring molten silver into a bullet mold. JANE (v-o concludes) ...and molded them into a silver bullet.

head_text.subj: INT. MAC'S GUN SHOP, WITH MAC AND UNCLE AL DAY

text: MAC comes out of the back with a small inlaid wooden box. puts it down on the glass counter top.
Here it is.

MAC'S hands open it, disclosing a single bullet resting o dark velvet plush. It is a .22 short round, and it gleams pure silver. It would be great to hype this bullet optically- not much, just a little- to make it look absolutely magical. Almost holy.
UNCLE AL picks up the bullet almost reverently, holds it the light.
Nicest piece of work I ever did, I think. It's got a low-grain load so it won't tumble. Should be pretty accurate.
It's just a gag, that's all. What would you shoot a silver .22 bullet at, anyway? MAC (joking) How about a werewolf? (Pause) Happy Halloween, Al.

It nearly fills the screen, swimming mysteriously in the warm summer air. JANE (voice-over) By the time Marty's silver bullet was done, it was Halloween... and the full moon had come around again. Earlier that afternoon, my grandfather, who had been dying of cancer for over seven years, finally finished the job. THE CAMERA PANS DOWN to the COSLAW house. There's a carve jack in the window and a corsage of Indian corn on the do UNCLE AL'S MG is in the driveway. The COSLAW station wago is just backing out. UNCLE AL and JANE stand in the doorw MARTY is slightly behind them in the Silver Bullet. NAN leans out of the car. She's wearing black, and she ha obviously been crying.
Remember, Al... we'll be at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston tomorrow night! Or at the funeral parlor. It's Stickney and-
-and Babcock, I remember. Now go on! The station wagon backs farther and NAN leans out again.
And don't open the door for any trick or treaters even if they come!
We won't! The station wagon backs out into the road and NAN pops ou again.
You kids go to bed on time! You've got school tomorrow!
If you keep doing that, you're going to bump your head, sissy. Give my love to Mama- tell her I'll see her Thursday.
I will- be good, kids.
'Bye, mom! Bye, dad!                                We wi The station wagon accelerates away.
Can I tell you kids something?
Sure, Uncle Al.
When me and sissy were kids, we were just like you two.
Yeah? Really?
Yeah. Really. The bitch of it is, we still are. Learn from your elders, dearies. He ushers them inside and closes the door.

location: THE STATION WAGON, WITH BOB AND NAN

text: I can't believe that you'd agree to leave the kids with him. A year ago I would have laughed at the idea. You used to almost breathe fire when Al came in the house.
He's changed. Just this summer. Or something's changed him. Marty, maybe. And the drinking- I think it's almost stopped. Whatever it is, it's wonderful. And they'll be safe with him. I'm sure of it.
I know they'll be safe with him... but will he get them both into bed by nine-thirty? NAN (firmly) If I told him to, he will.

head_text.subj: INT. THE WALL CLOCK IN THE COSLAW LIVING ROOM NIGHT

text: It reads 1:00. SOUND: The National Anthem.
The anthem finishes up. We go to a station ID card.
This concludes WDML's broadcast day. The TV goes to snow.
She's mostly asleep in one corner.
He's also dozing.

location: UNCLE AL, IN BOB'S EASY CHAIR IN FRONT OF THE TV

text: He is also dozing. There are three or four empty beer can in front of him, and a cigarette with a long ash is smoldering between his fingers. There's a .22 pistol in h lap.

location: THE COSLAW HOUSE, FROM ONE SIDE

text: The WEREWOLF breaks from the woods and runs across the si yard to a line of high bushes that runs along the side of the house (this is the opposite side from MARTY'S bedroom

location: IN THE BUSHES, WITH THE WEREWOLF

text: There is a space in here between the house and the bushes it's like an animal's run. The WEREWOLF creeps along this its one eye flaring. DIM SOUND OF TV SNOW.

location: THE LIVING ROOM, WITH MARTY, JANE, AND UNCLE AL

text: UNCLE AL jumps up and cries out as the cigarette burns up his fingers. The .22 falls onto the rug. MARTY and JANE also wake up, startled.

location: IN THE BUSHES, WITH THE WEREWOLF

text: It recoils, eyes gleaming. Foam begins to drip from its jaws. It creeps slowly along toward a window. TV SNOW SOU GROW LOUDER.

location: THE LIVING ROOM, WITH AL, JANE, MARTY

text: UNCLE AL is shaking his burned hand; he picks the cigaret out of his lap and puts it out. JANE (sleepy) You'll burn yourself up sometime doing that, Uncle Al.
I suppose so. You kids ought to go up to bed.
But Uncle Al! You said-
I know what I said, Marty- but it's ten past one. He's not coming.
The moon's not down yet...
Damn near. Now I'll sit up with this stupid gun in my lap because I promised, but you two are going to bed. Go on, now, scoot. JANE gets up and starts toward the stairs.
What if I say no?

Then I'd have to kick your ass, dear boy. (more kindly) Go on, now. MARTY begins to roll the Silver Bullet toward the stairs, where the stair chair awaits. JANE is waiting for him at living-room doorway. MARTY sees the gun on the floor and stops.
If that'd gone off, it would have been the end of our silver bullet.
He prickles a bit at the unstated criticism. He bends dow and picks up the pistol. He opens the cylinder. Five chambers are empty; in one there's a bright silver circle
He pushes the cylinder plunger, dropping the silver bulle into his hand.
See, dear boy? Totally unimpaired. Behind him, the WEREWOLF'S head appears in the window, it green eye flaring.

location: BY THE LIVING ROOM DOORWAY, WITH MARTY AND JANE

text: MARTY, looking toward UNCLE AL, sees nothing. JANE is looking toward the window and she SCREAMS. JANE (shrieking) It's him! It's the werewolf! I see him!
She's pointing at the window.

He jumps up and looks around at the window- at this point has the .22 with its cylinder open in one hand and the silver bullet loosely held in the other. Nothing in the window but darkness. UNCLE AL turns back t the kids. UNCLE AL (sharply) You see it, Marty!
MARTY (shakes his head) I was looking at you...

His shoulders slump a little with relief- now that the sc is over, his relief is tempered with irritation. They're just a couple of hysterical kids after all, and JANE is actually worse than MARTY. Polly Practical indeed!
A very familiar feeling is beginning to creep over me.

location: MARTY AND JANE, BY THE DOORWAY

text: JANE is crying.
What's that, Uncle Al?
I feel like a horse's ass.

location: MARTY AND JANE, BY THE DOORWAY

text: JANE (weeping) I saw it, Uncle Al! I did! MARTY rolls a little closer to her and attempts to put a comforting arm around her shoulder.
Don't you touch me, snotbrains!
Jane-
Would you kids go to bed? My head's starting to ache.

location: THE SIDE OF THE HOUSE, ECU

text: We see a clawed, hairy hand reach into the frame and clos around a thick wire. WEREWOLF (voice) Reeeal slow... It yanks.
The lights go out. JANE SHRIEKS.
It's here! It's outside!

Jane, it's just a power fai- He's starting toward her. At that moment most of the wall not just the window it was looking through before but the whole wall- crashes inward as the WEREWOLF bulls its way through, roaring. UNCLE AL whirls, raising the pistol automatically to fire but the cylinder is rolled out and all the chambers are empty. He has time to register surprise before the WEREWO smashes him aside.
He goes flying backward. The pistol goes one way, the sil bullet another.
It spins into a living-room corner.
We see it rise in the air, turning over and over. It come down, hits the floor, and rolls.

location: THE HALLWAY FLOOR, WITH THE BULLET, SLOW MOTION

text: In the extreme f.g. is a heating vent. The bullet is roll toward it.
Get the gun! He uses his hands to propel the ungainly Silver Bullet in the hall.

The silver bullet rolls slowly toward the heating vent. I the b.g. we see a frantic MARTY in his wheelchair. He heaves himself out of it and falls full-length, grabbi His fingers touch the bullet, but that's all. It falls in the heating vent.
It's roaring, furious, its one eye flaring.

UNCLE AL lies senseless against one wall, the front of hi shirt bloody. JANE runs into the corner and grabs the pistol. The WEREWOLF picks up the easy chair and throws it throug the hole it made coming in. It picks up an end table and hurls it through the TV. Then it sees JANE and starts tow her.
Comes toward her.
She makes as if to run one way.
It's only a couple of feet from her now, but again, it is toying with her- it's making this reeeal slow.
A bloodstained hand grabs a poker.

As it tenses down to leap at her, UNCLE AL leaps at it an strikes it across the back. It turns, ROARING. UNCLE AL hits it between the legs. It BELLOWS and grabs the poker. It bends it and tosses it aside. The glaring, savage expression on its face says th now it will bend UNCLE AL and toss him aside.
She breaks out of the corner and runs across the room tow the door. Most of the way there she trips and falls.
Its head whips around.
He's lying full-length. He's got the heater vent's grille off. One arm is down inside. MARTY (scream) Janey! The gun! THE GUN!
She tosses it awkwardly.
It slides down the hall floor to MARTY like some strange, awkward shuffleboard disc, its cylinder still open.
WEREWOLF (snarls) Maa-aaa-rty... It begins walking slowly across the living room, smashing things out of its way.
The gun slides into his hand. Now he reaches into the heating duct again...
There's an elbow bend just below MARTY'S twisting, graspi fingers- the silver bullet lies here. It's less than half inch out of reach.
WEREWOLF (foaming) Maaa-aaa-rty...
JANE (sobbing) Don't you hurt him! Don't you hurt my brother! She bites one of the WEREWOLF'S hairy ankles as it passes
It roars with pain and kicks her aside. Then it looks bac into the hall. It is grinning. I believe it is thinking t is going to be better than a Thanksgiving dinner you don' have to pay for.
Reeeal slow, Maa-aaarty-
He's reaching desperately into the duct and staring at th approaching WEREWOLF.
MARTY'S fingers brush the bullet once... again... seize i
He rolls over on his back and sticks the silver bullet blindly into one chamber of the cylinder and slams the cylinder closed.
Bastard Marty!
He points the gun and pulls the trigger. There's only a click. An expression of dismay on his face.
Kill you...
He drags himself so he's half propped against the hall wa He pulls the trigger again. Click! Dismay becomes fear.
It's reached the Silver Bullet. It smashes it aside. The Bullet hits the wall.
Holding the gun in both hands now, he pulls the trigger a third time. Click! The WEREWOLF'S shadow falls over him.
Bastard Marty! It bends down, reaching.
Craning back as if to drive himself into the wall, he pul the trigger again.
The bullet flies from the barrel, gleaming silver.

The silver bullet strikes him in his one remaining eye. H flies backward, hands clapped to his gushing face... and crashes into MARTY'S Silver Bullet wheelchair. It sits there, roaring... and then it begins to change.
She lies there, sobbing. UNCLE AL (voice) You okay, Janey?
UNCLE AL is bloody and staggering but on his feet. He hel JANE up.
I'm all right... but Marty! Ma- SOUND: SHATTERING ROAR.
Its hands drop from its face. It is now blind in both eye it is half WEREWOLF and half LOWE. It BELLOWS again, convulses... and dies.
MARTY (calls) I'm all right. He's dead.

Here's a creature that is mostly FATHER LOWE collapsed in the remains of MARTY'S wheelchair; beyond it, MARTY is ly on the floor. UNCLE AL goes by the corpse. JANE starts by and LOWE sits bolt upright for a moment, grasping blindly her. She shrieks and darts aside. LOWE falls back, now really dead. I think. Until the sequel.

location: THE HALL, WITH UNCLE AL, JANE, AND MARTY

text: UNCLE AL puts a comforting arm around JANE, who is sobbin again- hell, I'd be sobbing after that last one, myself- draws her down beside himself and MARTY. UNCLE AL (to MARTY) There. I told you there weren't any such things as werewolves. They smile at each other with love. JANE (nervous) Are you sure it's dead? Or him? Or whatever it is?

If it isn't now, it will be after I pound one of your mother's silver candlesticks through its heart. JANE (grimaces) Oh Uncle Al, no! UNCLE AL (grim) Oh yes, Janey. When I believe something, I believe it all the way. He gets up and leaves.
Are you all right, Marty?
All except my legs... I don't think I can walk.
You're a real booger, you know it? MARTY (smiles) I love you, Jane.

Quiet. Sleeping. JANE (voice-over) It wasn't always easy for me to answer that... but I could answer it that night, and I find I can say it now that the terrible events of that fall have receded to memories which seem little more than dreams in my mind.

location: THE HALLWAY, WITH MARTY AND JANE

text: JANE (hugging him) I love you, Marty.
JANE (voice-over; no more than a whisper) I love you, Marty... good night. THE CAMERA PANS UP to the full moon.
